Bastion is a hack n' slash role playing game, however this game has some really interesting aspects that contrast from other games inside the same genre.You play as "The Kid" someone that just woke up in the middle of a catastrophe that neither the player nor the character know anything about, however we can count on the strong presence of the Narrator to enlighten us during our adventure.I want my first point on this review to be exactly about the Narrator, something that really standed out from any game I've ever played. We are used to games which story develops over time with strong interactions between characters, or with the environment however in Bastion, every interaction is very  subtle, and that's where the Narrator comes in, as someone telling and unfolding a story and interacting as much with the main character as with the player himself which is awesome. And the developers really hit gold here, since first of all the voice fits perfectly on the western theme that surrounds the game, and at the same time the voice acting is also amazing, since you can feel every emotion which helps create a certain empathy with this being, and that's something fundamental in this story.Since we're talking about voices and sounds let's jump to the soundtrack, which after the Narrator is the best aspect of the game, since it manages to develop and transform according to the story which is phenomenal. You'll understand what i mean since it's quite rare to hear a soundtrack which contain tracks with lyrics, and even though I think that including something like that is risky since it could break the atmosphere of the game, it does exactly the opposite and traps you even more on this brilliant story.Now onto the gameplay, this is up to you to decide if it is a good thing or not according to your standards but to me it felt like the combat and exploration is something secondary. Don't get me wrong, the combat is fun and this aspect of the game is very well developed with a big array of weaponry, abilities and upgrades. The developers even managed to make this part of the game more interesting with the fact that all the way to the last part of the game you unlock a new mechanic, however it didn't feel as good as the plot, which was what really kept me going.The visuals are very interesting, the 2D visuals with the isometric camera really fitted into the style, nevertheless some models seemed quite odd, as an example the main character which on some drawings shows up as someone quite slim, when you look at the model you see someone quite bulky which doesn't make much sense. Same goes for Rucks which the model doesn't look that good either.Something that also bugged me was the fact that you're being told a story and all of a sudden the game gives you the option to make a couple decisions on the final stage and to me it felt out of place, I think you should be either given more choices to make or none at all. Although i think I'll play this game again someday I can't justify playing the main storyline for 5 hours again just to make a diferent decision at the end and see an alternate ending, but if I had more choices throughout the game I could justify a second playthrough immediately after the first one.Nonetheless I consider this game to be a master piece, the story is interesting, the length feels just right and the western/badass vibe throughout the game is an amazing experience.+ Great story;+ Fun mechanics;+ Amazing Atmosphere;- Some models are just ugly;- Lack of more decisions.92% cool game!Join my Steam Group page for more reviews: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/jereviews

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												If you like adventure games, you must give Bastion a try.The art, aesthetics, music, lore, and especially the great narration all combine to provide you with a refreshing adventure experience. The levels are very detailed, and the routes you can take are assembled in front of you as you walk (you can easily fall off the map, which will result in some health loss). There are many destructable objects in the game - this is indicated by the object flashing red whenever you hit it (most objects can be destroyed).As you play, a narrator comments on certain things you do. For example, you may come across a mechanical bull and, if you decide to attack it, the narrator will say something like: "the kid (you) gave him exactly what he deserved." The music also changes appropriately when you are in the heat of battle.The controls are very easy to use, however, the feedback prompts can get annoying (for example, when you are at less-than-half health, the keyboard key "F" will appear next to your character, along with "heal." These button reminders can be helpful, as the game will prompt you to block if you are taking constant damage, however, it can become repetitive if you arleady have mastered the controls.There are many weapons to unlock, and you can equip two at a time; you can also use your shield by pressing/holding shift. Blocking right before the moment an enemy's attack hits you will result in an autoattack. You reflect enemy projectiles if you block with the correct timing. There are a variety of special "secret moves" available, and you can equip one - you have to have the specific weapon the skill is bound to equipped. Later, you will also be able to select things like drink passives (provide bonuses like extra health) or "god" artifacts that make enemies stronger, but also provide you with a bonus to experience. Everything is upgraded with experience that comes in the form of little blue collectibles. You can select between uo yo 6 different upgrades for each weapon ( 3 active at a time).The game consists of you collecting cores/shards in each level in order to bring the "Bastion" base to life - each core you collect usually opens a new building slot in the Bastion, allowing you to select which building type you would like to build first (ex: armory for equipping weapons and skills, or distillery for equipping passive drinks). There are a variety of buildings, each unlocked for building as you progress through the story.There are also weapon challenge levels, where you have to perform a task like destroying a number of items with the hammer within a time frame. Each challenge level has 3 difficulty tiers, and beating the time for that tier yields a prize (1st place is always a secret move). The learning curve is very good, however, the game can get difficult if you use a lot of god trinkets (to increase enemey characteristics) - I equipped a total of 4 and would die from most enemies within 4-5 hits.The game is very charming and I strongly recommend it if you like adventure games with very nice aesthetics and narration.

												Bastion is, hands down, one of the best games I have ever had the fortune of playing. The visuals are incredibly appealing vibrant, fitting colours, detailed artwork. The western-theme nicely by the western music, which is very fitting on the game as a whole. The narrator's voice-overs and explanations for things are flawless and quirky, and make you want to hear more. The gameplay is great fun the combat, starting simple, becomes increasingly fast-paced and skill-based, especially when all idols are enabled for full difficulty. As you progress through the mysterious-yet-lore-heavy storyline, more weapons are unlocked, allowing you to play using different styles. You can eventually customize a "build" (a weapon loadout and some bonuses, called spirits). And the gameplay doesn't get old. Many games turn into grinding for levels, but Bastion encourages to play just to play. I am playing through the main storyline for the third time now, having already beaten it once in its regular story and difficulty, and another time in New Game with all idols activated. Replay-ability is very high, and I still have not grown bored of it.

Posted: July 19, 2014
												I just finished Bastion and really enjoyed it. Highly recommended!Gameplay: 8/10 -- Pretty standard stuff, i.e. everything you need from an isometric top-view style action-RPG. Not too complicated, not too simple.Visuals: 9/10 -- Really beautiful hand-drawn world, with a genuine "feeling" to it. Animation and cutscenes were also cool. I like how the world "came together" as you walked.Audio: 11/10 -- The music is fantastic and the "Narrator", accompanying you throught *all* the game, is just awesome. Easily the strongest aspect of the game.Story: 7/10 -- The story is OK, but there's too few characters (err, 4 of them!) and only a couple are really "explored". The world the game unveils is interesting, albeit tuned for "all ages" audiences.It took me about 12 hours to finish the game; the difficulty was quite OK, maybe a bit easy. I completed almost everything in the standard story-mode, and I didn't do any of "Game Plus", for the time being.Achievements (both in-game and steam ones) were quite finely tuned to my liking, keeping me reasonably motivated to play and earn more as I went.My sole problems were: (1) my no-name PS3-like USB gamepad wasn't recognised; typical... (2) Isometric top-view has the NE-SW and NW-SE as the two principal axes, so playing with WASD keys [N-S and W-E axes] was a little weird at first; but I quickly adapted.

												Bastion is, hands down, one of the best games I have ever had the fortune of playing. The visuals are incredibly appealing vibrant, fitting colours, detailed artwork. The western-theme nicely by the western music, which is very fitting on the game as a whole. The narrator's voice-overs and explanations for things are flawless and quirky, and make you want to hear more. The gameplay is great fun the combat, starting simple, becomes increasingly fast-paced and skill-based, especially when all idols are enabled for full difficulty. As you progress through the mysterious-yet-lore-heavy storyline, more weapons are unlocked, allowing you to play using different styles. You can eventually customize a "build" (a weapon loadout and some bonuses, called spirits). And the gameplay doesn't get old. Many games turn into grinding for levels, but Bastion encourages to play just to play. I am playing through the main storyline for the third time now, having already beaten it once in its regular story and difficulty, and another time in New Game with all idols activated. Replay-ability is very high, and I still have not grown bored of it.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												If you like adventure games, you must give Bastion a try.The art, aesthetics, music, lore, and especially the great narration all combine to provide you with a refreshing adventure experience. The levels are very detailed, and the routes you can take are assembled in front of you as you walk (you can easily fall off the map, which will result in some health loss). There are many destructable objects in the game - this is indicated by the object flashing red whenever you hit it (most objects can be destroyed).As you play, a narrator comments on certain things you do. For example, you may come across a mechanical bull and, if you decide to attack it, the narrator will say something like: "the kid (you) gave him exactly what he deserved." The music also changes appropriately when you are in the heat of battle.The controls are very easy to use, however, the feedback prompts can get annoying (for example, when you are at less-than-half health, the keyboard key "F" will appear next to your character, along with "heal." These button reminders can be helpful, as the game will prompt you to block if you are taking constant damage, however, it can become repetitive if you arleady have mastered the controls.There are many weapons to unlock, and you can equip two at a time; you can also use your shield by pressing/holding shift. Blocking right before the moment an enemy's attack hits you will result in an autoattack. You reflect enemy projectiles if you block with the correct timing. There are a variety of special "secret moves" available, and you can equip one - you have to have the specific weapon the skill is bound to equipped. Later, you will also be able to select things like drink passives (provide bonuses like extra health) or "god" artifacts that make enemies stronger, but also provide you with a bonus to experience. Everything is upgraded with experience that comes in the form of little blue collectibles. You can select between uo yo 6 different upgrades for each weapon ( 3 active at a time).The game consists of you collecting cores/shards in each level in order to bring the "Bastion" base to life - each core you collect usually opens a new building slot in the Bastion, allowing you to select which building type you would like to build first (ex: armory for equipping weapons and skills, or distillery for equipping passive drinks). There are a variety of buildings, each unlocked for building as you progress through the story.There are also weapon challenge levels, where you have to perform a task like destroying a number of items with the hammer within a time frame. Each challenge level has 3 difficulty tiers, and beating the time for that tier yields a prize (1st place is always a secret move). The learning curve is very good, however, the game can get difficult if you use a lot of god trinkets (to increase enemey characteristics) - I equipped a total of 4 and would die from most enemies within 4-5 hits.The game is very charming and I strongly recommend it if you like adventure games with very nice aesthetics and narration.

Posted: September 15, 2011
												Bastion is one of the best new games I've played in a long while. I guess technically it is an action-RPG, but not in the traditional sense (for example, it's very short and you only gain 10 levels maximum). But it's not even really the gameplay that is the main attraction anyways (at least not for me) - rather, it's the unique world you get to visit during those few hours. The world is visually beautiful and the soundtrack is amazing, but the main draw that keeps you engaged is the smooth-voiced narrator that tells the story of everything you do as you do it. It's hard to explain the concept properly since it is unprecedented in gaming, so all I can really say is check it out and see for yourself. The game itself is not very hard, so pretty much anyone should be able to finish it (there are also various options more experienced players can enable if they wish to make the game harder). I can't say enough good things about Bastion - it is practically a clinic in game design. Get it!

Posted: January 5, 2014
												Bastion is an amazing game, with entertaining gameplay, a unique and beautiful artstyle, and most importantly an intricate, thorough, and moving story. The gameplay and combat is fairly straightforward, but the combinations of two weapons and a single skill can allow for many styles of play, and the lack of straight upgrades adds to this dynamic as well. Additionally, the system of leveling up was unique and further added to the styles of play, and the difficulty of the game scales well, with additional options to offer a greater challenge. Regardless of the engaging gameplay, Bastion excelled in its storytelling. Told through amazing narration, you experience the story of the world of the Bastion. The environment is defined by the artstyle and the soundtrack (which is definitely worth a listen). What stood out most to me concerning the story, however, was its ability to invoke an emotional response from me. As someone who usually plays games for just their gameplay, the whole story (and particularly the conclusion) I was surprised at how much I actually cared about the kid and the characters he meets. Overall, Bastion is definitely worth a purchase. Decent gameplay in an amazing environment with an engaging story made for a great game.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												It would be remiss of me to begin this review without divulging that if the devs ever resolve to produce a Bastion: Revisited or likewise, I would jump for joy in my pajamas (and probably even pee a little) before insta-buying the game. My love for the game isn't even as strong as my love for procrastination, but it helped me reminisce about an older strategy game I played with similar mechanics.The plot itself is light and uncomplicated - with two choices towards the end. You play as a squat yet resilient Kid, who can wield weapons taller than himself, and dodge attacks with the agility of a jaguar. Tasked with restoring a brittle, post-apocalyptic world, you help him traverse various picturesque floating isles in search of resources while trying not to fall off ledges at every corner. Only a cockroach would survive a fall like that, not your protagonist.Pros : UI - Being able to move around via mouse while battling via keyboard was more satisfying for my hardwired brain than I can account for. You can also choose between complete keyboard control and gamepad. Besides that, the in-game screen itself isn't cluttered with unnecessary icons, which makes for cleaner gameplay.  Weapons - The assortment of murder tools at your disposal will be enough to make you squee. Moreover, they're colorful and have cool names. My personal favorites were the Spear, the Musket and (later on) the Galleon Mortar. The latter is akin to a pocket cannon, but looks and feels much cooler. The weapon upgrade system is unique too. Every time you unlock an upgrade, you can choose between two characteristics. For example, one upgrade for the Army Cabine (a long range, destructive rifle) offers a choice between activating either Faster Aim Speed or Bonus Damage.  Music - I often say this for other games, but it can be quite a challenge to create a good ambience with music. I wouldn't want hardcore metal blaring in my ears during a battle lest I get squashed by a giant hammer. Thankfully, the BGMs in this game keep you perfectly at ease, and are well paced . There are moments when you can hear Zia (the game's Nightingale) singing; it's the kind of voice I can fall asleep to. Mobs - Some are stationary and can be killed with ease. Some have armored heads, will collide into you with all their might, can only be poked if you stick a spear into their♥♥♥♥♥ and ARE FROGS. *internal zombielike laugh* Some can only be killed if you poke them in the eye enough times. (i.e.) They're pesky but they won't bore you. Cons : Bonus Stages - Each time you discover a new weapon, you can test it out in it's exclusive battle grounds to challenge yourself. The difficulty lies in the fact that most of the challenges require you to do something humanely impossible. Like aiming and shooting a random popping scarecrow in 2 seconds, or clearing a minefield of pin-spitting cushions in (what was it?) 1 minute? Since these add to the very charismatic Achievement system in game, which in turn provides resources for upgrades, I'd like to actually be able to complete them. Instead of having to hire a robot. Shrine - This may be appealing to masochists, but invoking ten or so idols to immortalize the already pestilent mobs is not something I can enjoy. Moreover, there's 8 steam achievements for accomplishing these. I don't mind the Shrine system itself, but be more realistic please... Duration - The game ended too quick.Scores Art - 10/10Music - 8/10Narration - 11/10Plot - 8/10Overall Score - 7/10 (would've given a 9 if I wasn't such an achievement hoe)

content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
												"Bastion" - if it wasn't for my friend, who knows I love good stories and good soundtracks I might have never tried this game. He got me a copy, and I got addicted.In the game, you play as the Kid, who wakes up, and finds his world is literally falling to pieces. The ground shatters beneath him, it's like something is devouring the land like a disease. And that something is called the Calamity. The Kid has to find his way to the Bastion, a place created to gather any survivors in case of a catastrophy. A place that is supposed to save to world. But through his travels the Kid meets other people, finds their stories, and then discovers the horrible truth about the Calamity, and the Bastion itself.It's an action RPG set in a two-dimensional world with an isometric camera. Sounds simple, and boring enough, right? Wrong! The world is beautifully painted, colourful and vivid. There is a vast number of different enemies and environments. You also have a large group of weapons to choose from, and create your own style of fighting. For me, I always prefered the war machete as a melee, scrap musket as ranged, and squirt lure as a special ability. But there is a number of combinations, and everyone will find something fitting. The gameplay is mostly hack&slash, not gonna lie. But the story is just gripping. You do get involved, you do get attached, and at some point, you will be forced to make a decision. And it is not an easy one, it squeezed a tear out of my eye.The soundtrack deserves its own review... From blues bar sounding "Slinger's song", through the sweet notes of "Build that wall", exciting and fun "Terminal march", and the beautiful, heartbreaking "Mother, I'm here", this soundtrack provides about an hour of eargasms... I listened to it for two weeks non stop, after I completed the game, it's that good.Oh, and I forgot the best bit. The whole game is narrated by a deep, warm voice. With a hint of sense of humour, a lot of sarcasm, and plenty of emotions, the narrator, also known as Rucks, creates an atmosphere of a campfire story, being told to anyone who dares to listen.Will you dare?

Posted: May 28, 2014
												I do not typically make it a point to write reviews. However, I would be ashamed of myself for letting the opportunity to share how much I love this game slip by. I have logged far more hours into this game than the counter would suggest, and have loved every single one of them.The story is polished and gripping. It unfolds in pieces, just like the world around you. Nothing is obvious at first glance, and every word spoken unveils new depths of emotion and connection to the characters and events without ever simply "giving it away."The narrator, Logan Cunningham, is unreal. His voice feels like sunlight, and the almost interactive way the narration plays into the gameplay leaves you always wanting to find out what else there is to be heard.Darren Korb's OST is one of the best I have ever heard, as many who have played would agree. The fusion of American Western and Middle Eastern sounds, with heavy and dynamic rhythms, is gripping. Not a single note is out of place as you wander, battle, and witness the twisted world around you. The fast songs get you excited and the somber songs shatter your heart.The gameplay is not particularly revolutionary, but it is well tuned and fun. The balance of difficulty and responsiveness allows beginners to enjoy themselves and pros to hone their reaction times and quick-thinking capabilities. The variety of weapons, skills, upgrades, spirits, and idols allows for a customizable experience that leaves you free to fight how you please. Balancing range and close-quarters? Tactical, strategic combat? Raw firepower? All are viable, playable options that leave you feeling pleased as punch.The art...is a blessing to the eyes. Unique, painstakingly handpainted beauty with every step you take. A beautiful fusion of styles create an atmosphere unlike any other, that seemlessly blends all aspects of the game together into a world that captures the imagination.Lastly, the characters and enemies are both enigmatic and relatable. Each character brings something powerful to the table, allowing players to connect on an emotional level - something very difficult for many AAA titles to accomplish. Enemies are well-designed and entertaining, leaving the player feeling ever-so-slightly guilty for their deaths...In short, absolutely the best indie game I have ever played, and one of the greatest that I own. In no aspect does it fail to live up to the standards that every game should aspire to. I hope, for the sake of your own experience and for the sake of the wonderful people who put so much love into making this game, that you wait no longer to buy and experience this masterpiece.

Posted: November 29, 2013
												Você vê este jogo em promoção, barato, talvez deva comprar. Vê a expressão pensativa do Kid e gosta das letras de "Bastion", e o nome também não lhe parece nada mal. Você olha os reviews, a maioria positivos, vê as imagens e pensa "ahhhhh, é mais um daqueles joguinhos".Minha situação é a do homem que está diante de uma obra de arte coberta, enquanto todos ao redor dele vêem apenas o pano vazio. Como explicar Bastion? Ele difere de vários outros jogos pelo simples fato de ser inteiramente narrado por um homem, mas não é "somente um narrador não-personagem". Ele não só está na história, como faz tudo parecer muito mais profundo sob a voz dele."Now here's a kid whole whole world got all twisted, leaving him stranding on a rock in the sky."Ele acorda, descobre-se sozinho numa ilhota de chão, no meio do céu. Como se tivesse dormido e tudo tivesse desaparecido, menos o chãozinho e o colchão. Mas quando ele anda, as pedras surgem e formam um caminho! Bom, você nada pode fazer senão seguir. O garoto encontra seu fiel martelo, e também alguns seres que antes trabalhavam como operário, mas por algum motivo resolvem te atacar.Para onde ele irá? Para o Bastion. Onde todos devem ir em caso de emergência. Mas ao chegar lá, esperando encontrar as pessoas, ele encontra primeiro um homem. "He finds me", diz o narrador. E então a verdadeira história começa.Bom, tudo parece estar suspenso no céu, então tem claramente alguma coisa errada. Você precisa então juntar Cores espalhados pelos... bom, pelos lugares restantes de Caelondia, porque os Cores têm poder e os mantém no lugar. Ao mesmo tempo você encontra alguns fragmentos, que, primitivamente falando, seriam como a "moeda" do jogo.A jogabilidade é bastante simples. Teclas para se mover, botão esquerdo do mouse pra usar uma arma, botão direito para usar a outra. Barra de espaço para rolar, shift para bloquear, botão do meio do mouse ou Q pra usar habilidade especial. A Calamidade aconteceu, mas você não sabe a causa, e ficará, durante o jogo inteiro, perguntando-se o que é isso. A cada Core reunido, você pode recriar um novo edifício em Bastion. E vamos dizer que reunir os Cores é... Bom, não quero estragar a surpresa.Você tem algumas armas que vai ganhando ao longo do jogo, e pode escolher duas delas pra usar. Cada arma possui cinco upgrades, e cada upgrade possui dois melhoramentos. Você escolhe um melhoramento de cada upgrade, podendo alterar quando desejar. Há poções que conferem efeitos passivos, um Achados-e-Perdidos, um Memorial com missões... E criaturinhas que você encontra, lembrando-se de que nem todos são seus inimigos.É um jogo fácil, pelo menos até você libertar os deuses do Santuário, que conferem mais dificuldade ao mesmo tempo que aumentam o ganho de Experiência. Há também os Proving Grounds, que são desafios específicos para cada arma(e um para o escudo). Alguns chegam a ser moleza, mas a maioria são mesmo desafios, e Bastion é um jogo completo, desafiador, profundo. Há também os "Who Knows Where", que são "desafios" onde o Kid dorme, e o narrador conta uma parte especial sobre determinada personagem.E no final, tudo terminará com uma grande decisão sua.Feito para ser completado duas vezes. Não digo isso porque "O jogo é tão bom que te dá vontade de completar de novo", de jeito nenhum - quando você completá-lo pela primeira vez, entenderá.Usei muitas palavras para meu jogo inde favorito, mas se eu só pudesse usar poucas, elas seriam "Esse jogo possui uma alma".

												An isometric action-rpg, Bastion is set in world after the events of the "Calamity", where you play as "The Kid" and attempt to restore the Bastion.Gameplay consists of using a combination of upgradeable weapons and skills in the form of 'Tonics' that you can buy and find in the wild. Very satisfying combat with customisable difficulty through 'Shrines' that can, for example, give enemies extra health and explode after death. Some of the best level design I have ever experienced in a game, in which the ground forms as you progress through the beautiful and varied levels of swamps, forests and ruined city districts. The sound design is also second to none, featuring briliant voice acting as well as an enchanting and at times, frantic soundtrack that perfectly captures the setting of each individual level. Bastion, can be played with a mouse and keyboard as well as a controller, although I myself preferred using an xbox controller. There is some replayability, in the form of new game plus modes unlocked by completing the main story. I heartily recommend this game to anyone and everyone, and is a personal favourite of mine.

Posted: March 17, 2013
												Bastion is a fantastic and colorful game that tells a heartwarming story. The game revolves around the narrator, a likable figure that dictates your actions and voices the game's story. He is quite unique, and unlike other narrators in games like "Thomas Was Alone" or "The Stanley Parable". I honestly can't quite explain it, you would have to play the game for yourself to see it. The gameplay is fun -- and even though animation isn't top-notch, you barely notice it. You have the ability to level-up, gaining new weapons and powers -- there's also plenty of secrets about the world to discover. Bastion's combat is fairly enjoyable -- and although challenging, it was not frustrating.Bastion forms around the choices you make. This includes the narration. For instance, during the beginning of the game, (if you destroy enough items) you are told the classic line: "Kid just rages for a while." Some of the other choices are more influential, of course. I was proud and happy about some of my choices, but filled with dismay over others. (And such is life.)Overall, this is one of the best indie games of all time. It's worth all $15, but if you wait long enough you can pick it up on sale (or in an indie bundle).Bastion is great for everyone, no matter what you like in a game.

												First off, this game is amazing, and a must buy.Let me tell you why this is so. This game has a very unique artstyle, and not in a bad way. This contributes alot to the atomphere of the game aswell.The main focus of the game, and the thing you'll be doing the most, is using various weapons to kill creatures, critters and other living things. The game ALSO does great in this part. The combat is responsive, and does not feel like a "mash-to-win" thing. It also requires an amount of skill to master. This is empathised by the game it self, as it has "Training Grounds" where you can unlock 3 tiers of rewards, depending on how good you do a task, where the third tier is perfecting the task (Which is very difficult). This combat system if what I'd call an "easy to learn, hard to master" kind of thing. The game has around 10 weapons, where around half of them are ranged and the other half melee. You also get a "secret skill" which is like a special move, but you can't use it all the time, it has a resource attached to it which you can hold 3 of. You can upgrade your weapons aswell, It's almost impossible to upgrade them all. That's all I'm going to say on that.Now I think it's time to talk about the story. It's great. I'm not a "story guy" as I apreciate good mechanics instead of a great story. But since this has great mechanics, I started to focus on the story aswell. Go buy this game. It's worth the price.

Posted: January 20, 2014
												Should you play Bastion if you haven't done it yet? In one word : YES. Gameplay-wise the game is very well done. You collect weapons, spirits, level up, upgrade you weapons, etc. The difficulty level is adjustable by use of idols : you practically invoke the gods who in return make your life harder :) . To be honest, i played the game 3 times using the idols just to get more achievements. It's a blast! To make it short, the gameplay is engaging and challenging at times. Now the best part of Bastion : it's music and graphics. About the music there is nothing to say except that it's gorgeous. You'll definetly download the soundtrack and integrate it in your playlist. The narrator does a fantastic job at depicting the story and describing your every action. The narrator is no more that person who talks only between mission. If you break a vase, he tells you that, if you defeat a boss, he's certainly got something up his sleeve to say. And all this happenes without becoming too annoying.The graphics are astounding despite the fact they are 2d (or at least the background is). In fact, this has an even more powerful impact on your perception than a game who has 3d graphics. Every detail in the game is finely drawn and you'll feel the urge to explore every nook and cranny just to see the vistas.So, what are you doing here reading ? Go buy the game!9/10

												Você vê este jogo em promoção, barato, talvez deva comprar. Vê a expressão pensativa do Kid e gosta das letras de "Bastion", e o nome também não lhe parece nada mal. Você olha os reviews, a maioria positivos, vê as imagens e pensa "ahhhhh, é mais um daqueles joguinhos".Minha situação é a do homem que está diante de uma obra de arte coberta, enquanto todos ao redor dele vêem apenas o pano vazio. Como explicar Bastion? Ele difere de vários outros jogos pelo simples fato de ser inteiramente narrado por um homem, mas não é "somente um narrador não-personagem". Ele não só está na história, como faz tudo parecer muito mais profundo sob a voz dele."Now here's a kid whole whole world got all twisted, leaving him stranding on a rock in the sky."Ele acorda, descobre-se sozinho numa ilhota de chão, no meio do céu. Como se tivesse dormido e tudo tivesse desaparecido, menos o chãozinho e o colchão. Mas quando ele anda, as pedras surgem e formam um caminho! Bom, você nada pode fazer senão seguir. O garoto encontra seu fiel martelo, e também alguns seres que antes trabalhavam como operário, mas por algum motivo resolvem te atacar.Para onde ele irá? Para o Bastion. Onde todos devem ir em caso de emergência. Mas ao chegar lá, esperando encontrar as pessoas, ele encontra primeiro um homem. "He finds me", diz o narrador. E então a verdadeira história começa.Bom, tudo parece estar suspenso no céu, então tem claramente alguma coisa errada. Você precisa então juntar Cores espalhados pelos... bom, pelos lugares restantes de Caelondia, porque os Cores têm poder e os mantém no lugar. Ao mesmo tempo você encontra alguns fragmentos, que, primitivamente falando, seriam como a "moeda" do jogo.A jogabilidade é bastante simples. Teclas para se mover, botão esquerdo do mouse pra usar uma arma, botão direito para usar a outra. Barra de espaço para rolar, shift para bloquear, botão do meio do mouse ou Q pra usar habilidade especial. A Calamidade aconteceu, mas você não sabe a causa, e ficará, durante o jogo inteiro, perguntando-se o que é isso. A cada Core reunido, você pode recriar um novo edifício em Bastion. E vamos dizer que reunir os Cores é... Bom, não quero estragar a surpresa.Você tem algumas armas que vai ganhando ao longo do jogo, e pode escolher duas delas pra usar. Cada arma possui cinco upgrades, e cada upgrade possui dois melhoramentos. Você escolhe um melhoramento de cada upgrade, podendo alterar quando desejar. Há poções que conferem efeitos passivos, um Achados-e-Perdidos, um Memorial com missões... E criaturinhas que você encontra, lembrando-se de que nem todos são seus inimigos.É um jogo fácil, pelo menos até você libertar os deuses do Santuário, que conferem mais dificuldade ao mesmo tempo que aumentam o ganho de Experiência. Há também os Proving Grounds, que são desafios específicos para cada arma(e um para o escudo). Alguns chegam a ser moleza, mas a maioria são mesmo desafios, e Bastion é um jogo completo, desafiador, profundo. Há também os "Who Knows Where", que são "desafios" onde o Kid dorme, e o narrador conta uma parte especial sobre determinada personagem.E no final, tudo terminará com uma grande decisão sua.Feito para ser completado duas vezes. Não digo isso porque "O jogo é tão bom que te dá vontade de completar de novo", de jeito nenhum - quando você completá-lo pela primeira vez, entenderá.Usei muitas palavras para meu jogo inde favorito, mas se eu só pudesse usar poucas, elas seriam "Esse jogo possui uma alma".

												Bastion is one of my favorite games in recent years. It also might be my #1 Indie game. Although there may not be anything completely original in this title, the way the game is presented feels different from the majority of games I've played. They keep a lot of tried and true mechanics (e.g. upgradable weapons and character, multiple levels categorized by zones, home base where you will upgrade and customize your character, and unlockable arena battles to test your skills) but they've added plenty of charm and character to this title that keep it fresh. The narrator is one of the most memorable parts of the game and you will learn most of the world's lore and story progression via his soothing voice. The controls are very tight and almost perfect. The way you can alter your difficulty with the idols you unlock is also a nice feature that forces you to adjust your fighting technique if you want to face these self-imposed challenges. I finished the game several months ago for the 5th time, but keep reminiscing about the music, weapon loadout and the final, tough-as-nails dream challenge.9.5/10

												Where to begin? This game is absolutley beautiful, from the soundtrack, to the different regions/"worlds", the art style, the very vibe it gives off; it is amazing. There is something so mystical and vibrant about the environment that I just can't put my finger on. The Narrator's voice also adds a lot to the game; he is the one who walks you through vivid memories and reflections of the characters in the game, and without hardly any clips or unskippable sequences to accompany it. No other speaking voice besides the Narrator's is used, and I honestly wouldn't have it any other way; his descriptions and story-telling is really all you need, and adds to the feel of the game in a very positive way.The story of the game itself feels fresh, and is very interesting if you can keep up with listening to the Narrator while trying to fight your way through intense enemy sequences, which is my only real gripe. Then again, its best to save time and works more fluidly for him to explain while you are fighting in the area he is explaining. If you want to know the fine details of the story, you really can't afford to zone out for too long, because he describes things in simple sentences (that do the job and do it fantastically), but make it all the more harder to refocus and understand what just happened.The gameplay is very smooth and just works. No complaints there. As you travel through each region, the ground literally places itself piece by piece out in front of you, adding to the beauty and mystical vibe of the game. I love all the different weapons and skills you can equip and upgrade to use in battle; it makes everything more diverse and suitable to your playing style, which is kind of a standard for an RPG, but the game has its unique twist all the same. A drawback is that if you die, you have to start that region/level all over instead of having a checkpoint to teleport to. The enemies are varied, but they seem to have the same themes depending on which part of the game you are in and/or what region/level you are playing. They are not too difficult to defeat, but you can make it more challenging by using Divine Idols which can make enemies more resistant to attacks, hit harder, etc.Overall, this game is simply gorgeous and all-around fantastic, involving some of the best art styles, music, and usage of a Narrator I've ever seen. I would definitley reccomend to anyone who wants a great adventure with a good story.

Posted: March 10, 2013
												This is one of very few action RPGs with a compelling story and good characters. If compelling stories and good characters are what you're looking for, play it. It's good. It's really good.It's not a stereotypical action RPG either. You start with your character waking up in his bed with all the world except the 10-foot radius around him just gone. When you walk, the world floats up and pieces itself back together in front of you. It's not only a cool visual effect. It's also part of the story's worldbuilding and a metaphor for the main character trying to piece his life back together after a catastrophic event that evidently left the world wiped out.Gameplay-wise, the action is skillful and fast -- much more skillful and much faster than I could handle at higher difficulties (note: difficulty levels are built into the game's lore, so that's pretty cool too). It's also fun and responsive, though the isometric perspective combined with the colorful levels and masses of objects and enemies alike moving around the screen at once, it can get confusing. It's never so confusing that it becomes unplayable, though. It just starts to feel a little like a bullet-hell shooter at times, and it's not even a shooter.The music's not getting out of here without a mention. I got the soundtrack in one of the Humble Bundles, and I've listened to it far more than any other video game soundtrack (except perhaps Metal Gear). It has an electro-western feel to it that's a bit difficult to describe. The lead acoustic guitar is tuned down to something odd that I tried out on my own guitar (note: just a simple open strum sounds cool in the tuning Bastion's music uses). There are vocals in a few of the songs, and they all come in at exactly the right time for the meaning of the song and the context in which they're played to punch you right in the feels. Sometimes, the music fits so well (mostly the instrumental stuff) that I didn't even realize it was there. It's incredibly unique for a game in the fantasy genre, and the same could be said of all the game's design, from art to writing to music and even to gameplay to an extent.Each weapon feels different and serves a different playstyle, which is more than can be said for nearly any other game in Bastion's genre. The Cael hammer, the default weapon and the one I used throughout nearly the whole game, feels like it has weight and power packed in every swing. The sword is quick and slicey, the guns are suitably punchy, and the bow is precise enough to feel great.If you thought Diablo was the king of the action RPG genre (any of the three), I request you try Bastion. At least in my opinion, it completely demolishes all three Diablo games in every area on which it contends (Bastion has no loot system, so there's no contest there): story, characters, art style, music, worldbuilding, combat, and probably a few I missed.Play Bastion. You'll be doing yourself a favor.

												Bastion is yet another example of games where the gameplay itself is only a secondary part of the experience. Hacking and slashing through hordes of repetitive creatures in an isometric 3D environment would've been quite dull, weren't for the appealing art style, the always present and distinguishing voice-over narration, and the excellent soundtrack. The story, while supported by an interesting lore that can be seen reflected throughout the art of the game, doesn't get really interesting until it's final third, concluding in a very satisfatory ending. Although a console port, Bastion works well with a keyboard/mouse setup and didn't present any technical issues whatsoever. A great - and quite short - game, definitely worth experiencing.

Posted: December 29, 2015
												So freaking good. Almost five years later, it's a timeless masterpiece that you just want to keep playing more and more. At its core, it's a pretty simple story but it manages to charm and captivate like no other. The voiceover narration embedded into the gameplay is so expertly done. The soundtrack is easily one of the best ever in any form of entertainment, creating a new genre by itself. Combat it very satisfying and the game encourages you to try out different weapon combos and experiment with upgrades. There's plenty of totally optional "proving grounds" where, even if you fail the challenge, you learn something about how to best use a certain weapon. It's really well designed. The the upgrading and weapons system is quite in-depth for a game that looks so deceptively simple and playful from its tone. Passive bonuses from potions are great. There's a dynamic difficulty system where the player intentionally makes the game harder for themselves in exchange for more EXP, which is genius.All the areas are diverse and different enough so that you don't ever feel like you're doing the same thing twice. The handpainted environments are drop-dead gorgeous, only enhanced by the amazing soundtrack.I could go on for hours, but just buy the game. It's that good.

Posted: January 4, 2016
												Bastion is labelled as an action role-playing game but feels more like “hack and slash” dungeon crawler due to its gameplay presentation and isometric view.  Bastion is set in a steampunk-like, post-apocalyptic fantasy world.  Quite a mouthful.A moving painting of watercolour, ink and chalk comes to mind when travelling the different areas.  The world builds as you walk along, summoned from the bottom of nothingness up right to your feet creating the area.  It fills it with which seems to be the destruction of a civilisation as well as nature moving back in or claiming it with either lushes green, invading and threatening red and sometimes the dull marshiness colour pallets.  It is definitely a visually crisp and stunning game.The story is simple enough to follow but details of the world may be lost due to how the story is presented.  You play as “The Kid”, pretty much a nameless character that not even the narrator cares enough to ask for his name.  You go through the City of Caelondia and other areas in the world collecting these crystal-like objects called Cores that will help rebuild the world.As you play, there is a dynamic voiceover by a narrator that presents the story as well as comments your unique actions in gameplay.  There is a sense of a tragic storybook feeling and the use of third-person narration (and sometimes second-person), there is disjoint between “you” as the player and “you” as “The Kid”.   You may be able to make choices in the game but “The Kid” is not you but you play as “The Kid”.  Bastion feels like a viewing of an active story instead of “playing” it.Bastion feels like a cross between a twin-stick shooter/action game and dungeon crawler.  Waves upon waves of enemies attack you and with a large variety of weapons and able to carry two of them and a unique skill, the combat is definitely fun and experimental.  Would you like to be up close and personal and later attack from a far?  You can equip a melee weapon of differing methods of damage, such as the hard hitting but slow “Cael Hammer” or the quick and range weapon able “War Machete”.  Range weapons also vary from the machine-like crossbow “Fang Repeater”, to cowboy-like “Dueling Pistols” or one-shot, long range accurate “Army Carbine”.Enemies have attack patterns that can be learned but I still found them challenging in terms of timing that hacking and slashing is the way to go most of the time.  One example of an enemy is the “Gasfella”.  Varies in a different sizes, where their damage differs as well as their pattern timing.  Then there are “Gasfellas” that spin attack, dash attack or destroys part of the world beneath your feet.Bastion has high replay value even with the new game plus feature, giving you the ability to experiment with all the weapons from the beginning as well as toggling “idols” that modifies enemies and increases the difficulty and challenge.I found the world immersive and wanting to learn more from it.  I hope it would be expanded with the mention of different tribes skilled with each weapon and how they contribute to the world.  I want to learn more about the different cultures, clashes and history of this world and replaying it again will allow me to be more attentive to it because I found the details easy to be missed because of the dynamic narration, either being distracted by fighting or roaming around.  However, its presentation of the story feels intentional.  Where the calamity has destroyed the past and is now told through the elder and experiences of the other characters becoming folk tales.Definitely a recommend.

Posted: October 2, 2015
												Beautiful game with very simple mechanics but very competent at what it does. Carried by it's narrator, the story and the art style!The game itself is an isometric 2D action game with some very simple RPG elements. You can equip 2 weapons at anytime (each weapon can be upgraded 5 times and each time you can choose between two impromvements) from a growing arsenal of very different weapons. 2 melee weapons? 2 ranged weapons? A shotgun and a hammer? A bow and a machete? That's all up to you! Each weapon plays completely different and adds a lot of variety. Additionally you can equip a special skill for one of your 2 weapons or a weapon independent skill. You got also a shield to block and counter (with good timing) enemy attacks, a dodge roll and a button to drink heal tonics. So the basic mechanics are very simple but always spot on.  So while inexperienced gamers will probably enjoy this game (there is even an easy mode if you basically just want to enjoy the story), there are also a lot of challenges for hardcore gamers. For each weapon there is a location with a certain challenge and depending on how you perform you can unlock upgrade materials and skills for this weapon. While acing each challenge can be quite difficult (and rewarding) all this is completely optional. So if you don't like a weapon, there is no need in doing these. You can also invoke so called idols, basically deities, that each will add a certain challenge to the game. Enemies may just get tougher, drop bombs at death, deflect your attacks, and so on. But each invoked idol also increases the gained ingame currency and experience gained. So you can nicely tailor the difficulty to your likes.But the main reason, why you should play this game: The narrator. He will narrate and comment almost everything you do with such an awesome voice, it will get stuck in your head. For each weapon combination you equip, for each level you have to redo, because you failed the first time, he got a comment for you and the way he narrates the story is just beautiful. The story itself is also quite touching but is really supported by the way (and voice) of narration. The art style is also amazing and fits perfectly into the game and the story told.The first playthrough took me about 7 hours (with almost everything done) but I just started with NewGame+ that unlocks additional idols and let's you keep you all your upgrades. It's also nice how NewGame+ fits in with one of the 2 possible endings (you can choose between them in the end).The only thing I can actually critizise about this game is that restarting the weapon challenges takes a bit too much time if you already know that you can get the high score anymore. But that's also just a few seconds. And that you cannot replay levels that you've finished (you may have missed certain items) but that makes sense within the story.  Yeah...this game is awesome! Buy it!

Posted: June 29, 2014
												A simple yet deep action game that plays well depending on your choice of controlsUpon first look into this top-down action game I was compelled to report that this was a simple game with simple mechanics, simple game play and a simple story.  Not soon after I completed the first area did I come to the understanding just how much depth was contained within this game despite the simplicity of the mechanics.  Bastion truly is an experience to be had despite its unorthodox art-style, soundtrack and narrative.  Like many games of the indie genre, it is a refreshing break away from the mainstream but still contains the clean and somewhat polished look of many mainstream action titles that holds a place for both casual and competitive gamers.  This title is not without its quirks but contains a wholly unique experience that drives players from area to area.The story of Bastion is one of hope and survival.  Though not being terribly deep, the story is able to propel players from each area to the next.  It is not one given to gamers in a mainstream way.  It comes to players as if they are hearing a story given from the perspective of a  soothing-voiced supporting character.  Though the narrative was told in a story-like fashion, I never felt like it forgot about what was happening on the screen.  It was interactive and reacted to what my character was doing in the various areas. The story tells of the Calamity, a single apocalyptic even that lays waste the land and has released many monsters to impede your progress.  Few people remain and those that you find on your journey join you at the Bastion, a safe haven and the future of your people.  You begin your journey as a boy that has just awoken to find the effects of the Calamity and is being lead by the narrative to the Bastion.  You begin to rebuild the Bastion that will save the world and must traverse many hostile areas to find crystal shards that give the Bastion core power to rebuild.  On your journey you meet just a few characters that add depth to the story.  They merely give information and are not intended to physically aid you in your journey.  They story unfolds into one of treachery and deceit and has you make a few very difficult decisions as you approach the end of the game.  Though initially surface level, the story become one that some players may become emotionally engaged in.  Overall, the story is great and the experience is solid.When it comes to game play in Bastion simplicity is the name of the game.  Everything from the controls to the mechanics scream simplicity.  This is not to be confused with the game being simple however.  There were many instances where I began slapping keys out of frustration on a particularly difficult segment of the game.  The top down action genre has generally been associated with games like old school Grand Theft Auto and Diablo, but Bastion brings a more hack n' slash element to the genre with its various weapons and real time action.  Initially there are just the basic moves such as the primary and secondary weapon actions.  There are simple dodge and defend mechanics as well.  However not far down the path you begin to realize that there are many seemingly trivial elements introduced during the opening area that are absolutely crucial to be successful in the following areas.  I was pleasantly surprised to come to an area where I was to only surpass by timing counter attacks perfectly or practice efficiency with a weapon by only being allowed a certain amount of shots.   Bastion is not without its quirks however.  Having the PC title allowed me to choose whether I wanted to use the keyboard and mouse or a game pad.  I was able to try both as I had an old Xbox360 controller lying around.  After some time and a sideways expression, I came to find that depending on the weapons you chose to utilize on your journey, your choice of input greatly decided the difficulty or simplicity of the game.  I found that using a mouse an keyboard was more difficult because you had to manually aim shots whereas the game pad had a lock-on feature.  I also found that navigating the world of Bastion was much more intuitive with a game pad.  However, the keyboard and mouse offered much greater ease when it came to using weapons that had area of affect damage because I could aim at a group as opposed to an individual enemy.  Overall, the game pad was easier to use on a far greater range of weapons.  In the end, I ended up using both my keyboard and mouse and the game pad.  This I felt was a quirk that could have been resolved by implementing an auto-aim feature on either input device that could be turned on or off on the fly.  The would have prevented the need to sometimes constantly switch input devices.  If a player has the Xbox360 version of the game, they are most definitely limited to using just a game pad as the Xbox360 does not support mouse input.I feel that Bastion is a very unique experience that anyone can enjoy.  It allows users to merely play a decently designed game or get engaged into the story.  It does so many things well that its easy to overlook its input quirks.  It allows for gamers of all skills and gives an engaging 4-6 hour experience.

Posted: November 2, 2013
												You are greeted by the gruff voice of a stranger. A voice that will be your guide, your mind and your comfort for the next six hours. You play the character of an unnamed Kid, who's job is to protect himself and other survivors from the aftermath of a calamity, and make ends meet on The Bastion: your safe haven. To do this you have to collect cores from the various locations around The Bastion and return them.During gameplay you look down upon The Kid and fend off enemies' attacks. You can improve your weapons back at The Bastion and the narrator will comment on your progress.The voice of the narrator and the soundtrack are the two things that bring the game from fun to brilliant. “Windbags ain’t much different than normal folks,” the narrator says as you crush one of the game’s enemies with your hammer. “All they want is a place to stay and a decent meal.” This makes smashing them that much harder. As for the soundtrack, it suits the mood perfectly; the whole experience drips with passionate artistry. If you are thinking of buying this game, you have no idea what you are getting into. You will come to know of the beauty of Bastion, but you shall never understand it.

Posted: July 13, 2016
												A quick TL;DR, if you're buying the game on the spot; the interface is good, the story is interesting, the combat system is fun, just buy it if you're into the genre.The Interface is surprisingly user friendly. It's compatible with all sorts of things, from controllers to your plain mouse and keyboard. They're all pretty intuitive and easy to learn, so you'll get used to the controls quickly. It's also got your usual subtitles and your audio settings. You can have different profiles, which allows you to start over from scratch without destroying your perfect save. Tons of resolution options, too. Generally pretty solid.The story is pretty vague at first; you're a kid, well, you're The Kid, you wake up on a floating island miles away from sea level due to some apocalyptic event, and an omnipresent narrator voice is talking to you, describing your every move. I'd rather not go any further with the story (and you've heard this tons of times. Believe me, I also get tired of hearing this, but this is for real): you should experience it yourself. Supergiant prides itself on digging out lore out of seemingly nothing, it's practically a talent. This game has amazing replayability and you can easily get lost just slashing through everything. The game includes idols that will rise the stakes if you find it too easy. Oh, and the combat system? Love it. I'm biased, since I love hack and slash games, but this game features a diverse cast of weapons that you can mod for extra perks, letting you cherrypick your favorite perks. Will you go for extra damage, or settle for a higher critical chance? Besides weapons, you can drink spirits that will give you passive perks, from extra resistance to retaliating damage.There's not much that I can say about the artwork that hasn't been said. All of the art for the game is very impressive and, to top, very fitting. To close this, since we're talking about art, there's a reason the game is tagged with great soundtrack. The music is also very unique, the artist even giving it its own name (I seriously cannot remember what he called it, but it was a mouthful). Adds a lot of character to the game.Buy it. At best, you'll love it and play it again, and again, and again (or not, it's a 6-11 hour long game), at worst you'll play it once and be kind of okay about it. But if you're bent on getting all those achievements, you will clock out more hours than that. Just go play it. It's art.

												Short version: It's a good game with an awesome atmosphere and audio. Honestly it's too good to be an indie game and for it's price I'd definitely recommend buying it especially if it's on sale.What is Bastion? Well for me it was not only a game, but also an experience like Journey, Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons and other similar games. An experience that I will always remember.The gameplay is pretty simple: you move around the isometric maps and kill enemies and occasional bosses using a variety of melee and long range weapons. A more interesting twist is that later on you can set difficulty level you want by activating up to ten shrines that give various buffs to your enemies. Playing certain levels with all of the shrines active can be quite challenging. There is also a "New Game+" option when you finish the game and since it has multiple ending it can be worth having second playthrough.The visuals are very nice. Each level is beautifully drawn and the level builds up under your feet as you move which makes the overall look even more appealing. The sounds. There are two sides worth mentioning. The music and the Stranger. The music is really good and fits the game great. I'd probably think about buying it if I hadn't gotten it together with Bastion in the Humble Bundle. The Stranger is this games most known feature. He is the narrator that talks about you and your journey with a deep and very nice voice. He is so popular they even made a Bastion announcer for Dota 2.All in all this game will probably leave a lasting memory and is a great experience. I have really enjoyed playing it and it's definitely worth it's price. I would definitely recommend you to try Bastion. You will not regret it.

This Raises My Platforms - An Official Waffle King Review~Find more here.[lordwaffleking.com]Morgan Freeman narrating anything makes it infinitely so much better. Unfortunately, not too many games feature Morgan Freeman. A rookie mistake. I mean, why would you specifically decide not to? Game design 101 here.But worry not. Some people still know how to make a game. I mean, it's not technically Morgan Freeman. But it's close enough.Bastion, a nifty fully-narrated action-RPG, is one of those games. It's one of those indie games. From India. They sure know how to make stuff down there.The world has broken into a million little pieces. And it's up to you to raise them all back up, by hitting things and walking around.An especially story-driven game, Bastion has an immersive, almost seductive atmosphere. The world is painted colorfully and vividly, the story told through short narrated clips. Like listening to your grandpa tell a story."Eeyup. And then he walked over here, and hit the bad guy with a hammer. Mmmhmm. 'Course, back in my day we called 'em grizzly beaters. Those bears were always trying to climb through our windows, cause back then they were made of bubble-wrap. Eeyup, I remember the first time I fought a grizzly. My old hammer, we always called 'em Ol' Sledgie, we done fought a lot of bears together. But that was during the war, and President Truman said that there were tiny Japs piloting the bears. Aim for the back of the neck, they'd say. If you caught one, they'd take you to their pot of gold. Sweet, sweet gold. Just a few bars and you could afford real windows. But they had to have bumps on them to look like bubble-wrap, otherwise the bears would get smart and come through the chimney. Mmmhmm."That's my interpretation of the game.So much of the story's power and emotion comes from the voice-acting. It's really quite phenomenal. The sound design in general is fantastic, and the soundtrack is a joy to listen to. There's something about listening to an old guy ramble on to the sound of acoustic strings that just works. It melds perfectly together, and gives the game a sort of western frontier vibe. In addition to grandpa's stories, there are quite a few powerful gameplay sequences that convey emotion perfectly. Bastion doesn't rely on holding your hand through cutscenes or long walls of text. The most tense and emotional scenes will be directly controlled by you, the player.Of course, the almost hypnotic narration and sort of old-timey western vibe aren't the only things this game has in common with some of grandpa's stories.Because this game is empty as ♥♥♥♥.The story might go on and on, but there's no real substance to it.As far as action-RPG's are concerned, Bastion is really not all that special. You'll discover a multitude of weapons throughout your quest, a mix of melee and projectile. There's quite a few of them. And you can equip two at a time.But each weapon is just what it is. The knife cuts. The hammer smashes. The gun shoots. There's no real depth to any of the weapons, and the battle system is just dull because of that. You can collect special skills too, but those require using up "skill tonics" and don't generally do much more than kill things faster and flashier.You'll enter a level, spot a monster, run over to it and mash the attack button until it's dead. Repeat until you beat the level.There's no depth, no substance, no hook to the gameplay. It's like your mom made broccoli and cheese, but you just licked the cheese off and left the broccoli. No one wants to eat the broccoli, because it tastes like♥♥♥♥♥ They just want the cheese. The outer part of the game is perfect, and you'll savor every moment licking it clean. But when you get down to its core, it's just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥broccoli. Or ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥broccoli. That hyphen makes all the difference. Gross.As I progressed through the game, unlocking new weapons and skills, the game started to drag on quite a bit. I'd found a few weapons that I liked using, and generally gravitated towards and stuck to those weapons. Certain levels all but required using specific weapons, leaving you at a severe disadvantage if you didn't.But some weapons were just genuinely not fun to use or felt poorly balanced compared to other weapons. I just found a play-style I liked and tended to stick with it. Whenever I'd try other combinations of weapons, they didn't always work the way I'd wanted them to.There are mild customization options to each weapon, allowing you to do things like make your gun more of a sniping gun or more of a rapid-fire gun. Things like that. A nice touch that adds a bit more RPG to an otherwise bland button-masher. But it doesn't help too much in alleviating the repetitive gameplay.But not only did I play through the rest of the game after it started dragging on, I enjoyed it all. The atmosphere is really that good. Of course, when presented with the option to play the game all over again in New Game+ I did certainly hesitate.It's a fantastic gem of a game, and the design is definitely aesthetically pleasing. The gameplay might be a bit hollow, but it's still tolerable. It's definitely worth at least one playthrough. The world it paints is truly beautiful and touching, and really captures a specific essence in its story-telling. It's different, it's unique, and it's incredibly well-executed. I enjoyed my time with the game quite well.Fighting monsters? That's a paddlin'.Saving the world? That's a paddlin'.Upgrading your gear? That's a paddlin'.Talking to white, moustachioed Morgan Freeman? That's a paddlin'.This game's voice-acting?Oh, you better believe that’s a paddlin’.

												Bastion is a unique game in the sense that it focuses on narration. There is this dude telling you about the destruction of the old world caused by the Calamity, and you are set on a quest to obtain Shards, pieces of the old world so that you can rebuilt it.During this journey, you will discover:- A variety of weapons each with their unique special skill(s)- A variety of upgrades to each of these weapons- A unique challenge for each weapon to see how good you are with it, with the 1st prize usually requiring a number of tries- A few side quests where you fight waves of enemies to find out more about each character(May have a few more but these are the highlights for me.)The game play can be really easy or hard. This is because you can choose to invoke a number of Idols (up to 10) at the Shrine, each giving enemies a unique power-up. I played the last few levels with 6 Idols invoked, cos any more and I would fail and had to restart.At the very end, you have to make two choices that will directly affect the end screen. The second choice will also trigger two separate steam achievements, so achievement junkies like me will have to replay the game on new game +. While there isn't much replay value (enemies don't get tougher automatically), I guess you could invoke all 10 Idols for the maximum difficulty.Overall amazing art and great soundtrack with average game-play (gets old). I think the narrator did a great job, and he even has an announcer pack for Dota 2!8.5/10

Posted: September 22, 2013
There's a short pro/con list at the end of this review, if you don't feel like reading this whole bunch of text.ReviewBastion is one of those games you just have to fall in love with 'cause it's incredibly intriguing from the very beginning.The story takes place in the fictional city of Caelondia and its surroundings, now fractured because of a catastrophe called the Calamity. The Calamity broke the world apart and turned nearly all its inhabitants to ash. Now, the pieces of this world float in the sky, and the Kid (the protagonist of the game) awakens on one of these pieces. He sets out to reach the Bastion, a place said to be safe in times of trouble.One of the many things I love about Bastion is how you build the world around you by exploring it. Your path forms in front of you as you fight your way through enemies and investigate the area. This, as well as the use of vivid colors, make the world feel very lively, despite the destruction the Calamity has brought upon Caelondia.Also, the soundtrack is amazing. Seriously, buy it, it's gold.Bastion is labeled as an action role-playing game, but I would specify that and call it a hack-and-slay game because of its focus on combat and variety of weapons (you're welcome to disagree with that point, but I think genres to be quite squishy anyway; Bastion just feels more like a hack-and-slay game to me). There we have another thing I love about this game: you can choose from plenty of weapons and combine them any way you want.There are 11 unique items, either melee or ranged weapons, and you can carry two at once. By default, you equip one melee and one ranged weapon, but you can replace them anytime at the Armory. You want to carry two melee weapons, for example your trusty Cael Hammer AND the War Machete? No problem. Two ranged weapons, let's say, the Scrap Musket in combination with the Breaker's Bow? Why not?The third equipment slot is reserved for Secret Skills you find, win, or buy later in the game.There are many more possibilities to customize your character, for example Spirits providing passive bonuses; let's just say, you can choose equipment from a REALLY great range of thingies.My favorite thing about Bastion, though, is the narrative style. The Kid himself is silent throughout the whole game, but there is a narrator whose voice accompanies the protagonist, providing the player with background information and reacting to what he or she chooses to do.The voice is so incredibly great; really calm but rough at the same time. It feels like it belongs to an older, experienced man who grew a little tired of all the stuff happening around him after years of turmoil - and I think that is perfect. You get the feeling that you're hanging out in a pub, and you meet an aged man who tells you stories about his life as a young adventurer. This may be the greatest thing about Bastion - that you feel like you get to know the narrator, like he personally speaks to you and no one else.All in all, I think Bastion might be one of the most beautiful games set in a post-apocalyptic world I've ever played. The art style and soundtrack go so well with the atmosphere, and the narrative style is breathtaking. The gameplay is really fun and allows for a lot of customization. I already recommend it to anyone who's into video games, and I don't think you would regret playing it.Short list for everyone who's too lazy to read this:• multiple endings• playtime (first run, didn't finish 100 % of the game) approx. 11 hoursPros:+ beautiful graphics+ amazing soundtrack+ 11 unique weapons (melee as well as ranged weapons), all upgradeable+ high customizability (e.g. weapons, Spirits, etc.)+ extraordinary narrative style+ stunning voice acting+ collectibles and side quests/challenges (e.g. mementos, proving grounds for each weapon, vigils)+ great control over difficulty level (you can activate up to 10 Idols, each making enemies stronger in some way and rewarding you with more XP and fragments in return; great system in my opinion)Cons:- New Game+ Mode doesn't offer anything too special

Although there may not be anything completely original in this title, the way the game is presented feels different from the majority of games I've played. They keep a lot of tried and true mechanics (e.g. upgradable weapons and character, multiple levels categorized by zones, home base where you will upgrade and customize your character, and unlockable arena battles to test your skills) but they've added plenty of charm and character to this title that keep it fresh. The narrator is one of the most memorable parts of the game and you will learn most of the world's lore and story progression via his soothing voice. The controls are very tight and almost perfect. There is also a pre-unlocked "no sweat mode" for people who want an easier play-through.I found no bugs in this game at all, it is really well-polished.This game is really worth a play if you like story-driven games, and if you like a (apocalyptic) fantasy type of setting.

The game hits you hard with major challenges early on, and steadily ramps up the difficulty while also providing a lot of new weapons and concepts to the player steadily. What's more, the game never keeps you pinned down in one spot for too long. There's always some new interesting weapon combo to try out, and new challenges to try them out on. The narrator and story presentation tie into this perfectly, keeping the storyline moving at a good stint along with the rest of the game. Bastion isn't a very long game, but it's a very dense experience - there's a lot to take in during that short time period, on all levels.

												7/10 - Charming game, fun combat, rewarding upgrade system, an interesting story and setting, and of course the narration really makes it shine. Not much to say that hasn't already been said. Goes on maybe a bit longer than I'd have liked, and there were a few points here and there that felt either unfairly difficult (some of the challenge arenas basically requiring absolute perfect economy of movement/action) or far easier than the plot would have suggested (most of the major encounters towards the end of the game felt rather inconsequential despite the increasing significance). Posted: November 24, 2014
												Bastion is a visually spectacular work of art that is nothing like what you expected it to be, but in a good way. Game play wise, Bastion doesn’t bring many new cards to the table, but what it does, it does well. This is a mechanically strong hack and slash RPG with a few nice touches such as good selection or varied weapons, all of which are upgradeable, the ability to pick your own difficultly by “worshiping” certain gods, a home base which can be upgraded throughout the course of the game, and a spirit (the beverage) based system which lets you tailer the your character to your own tastes.The game itself is focused almost completely on fighting your through levels, upgrade your weapons and fight your way through more level, which this might come across and bland, to some, the constant stream of upgrades keeps it fresh as you unlock new weapons and abilities which often keeps you wondering what reward will you encounter next.All levels appear to be hand painted affairs, which rival the art in games such as Braid and Capsized, they consist of parts of a once prosperous, but now shattered floating city, the parts of which literally fall into place as you explore the landscape, an effect which doesn’t seem to get too old. As you explore the levels, the narrator, voiced by the seductively smooth Logan Cunningham explains what you are seeing and how the world used to be, occasionally commenting upon your own actions which bring you into the game, often purposely steering from the task at hand and even throwing yourself off a platform to see how he would respond.The music is brilliant in its own right, comprising of a generally “wild west” theme mixed with more contemporary beats and the occasional South Asian flavour, offering some stand-out tracks which are pleasant and also relevant to the characters and their stories.The story itself was diverse enough to make one invest in their character and the world, with enough subtle twists that one would find it genuinely interesting and caring about how the characters would be affected as the story unfolds.Although the 3D models of the characters were adequate, they do stand out against the beautiful 2D hand-painted backdrops of the broken world, a not to forget the ease at which one could fall off the platforms in some situations. Where this game shines is the presentation, everything from the outstanding narrative, to the story, art and music which are all of a high quality and to experience more of it is what really drive this game forward.

												The customer came to the Steam Reviews section.  Paged down, paged down. What the hell was this one? It seemed to be talking about them, instead of to them, about the game Bastion.  "What the hell is this?" the customer thought to themselves. They considered it. Isometric - the long flat angles of hand-drawn artwork. Was it like Diablo? The ranks of monsters, of course, but were they demon-maddened, suffused with the craving for additional credit card transactions? No, definitely not, surely someone would say that if that was happening. An ordinary tale, simple characters moving direct to what they desired, and a story you could feel unspool like a cat with a ball of yarn. But what dark thing lurked beneath the fluffy colored twine? What was the thing that would roll out before you at the end and make you look back at all the mess you made? The review didn't say. The customer clicked "Add to Cart".  The customer clicked "Add all DLC to Cart". It was that kind of night.

												Bastion is a strange game best known for it's narrator which is more like a commentator but is done so well that you never get annoyed by him repeating itself.The art is amazing as the ground raises from the bottom of the screen so you can walk on which makes exploring and finding secrets very rewarding.
