												Bastion is one of those games that catches you on the first two minutes of playing. Features lots of perks which, even if we are used to it, the game itself just gives you a well-rounded complete experience, be it you want a challenging game or just a good hearing at the beautiful story of the tribulations your character has to complete. Bastion, in a few words, is a game to remember.

												Admittedly, I missed the Bastion hype train when it came chugging past in 2011 and had only ever heard of a brief description of it being 'good' from people around me. How I missed that goodness knows but after playing Bastion I can only say that it completely lives up to the hype around it.In an action RPG hack and slasher, you play as a character simply called The Kid. What unfolds is a story where there is no 'good' or 'bad' but instead a morally grey area for a majority of the characters which leads to some interesting perspectives. The story is told by the narrator who comments and narrates almost everything you do as The Kid. Perhaps people can see this as being a gimmick for the game but I personally found it delightfully charming and enjoyed listening to the commentary as I played. It helps to try the story forward and serves as encouragement if you should get stuck to keep going. The only gripe I have about the story is that I would've liked to have a bit more of it, plus one of the decisions that you're forced to choose at the end doesn't seem to have much of an effect on the end story.Graphically the game is stunning, even living up to the standards of 2014. Seeing the ground rise up around my character as I walked was stunning and helped to keep the pace of the game. Every area has been designed carefully so there's a lot to see and do in a story that is around 5 hours long. The foes you come up against have all had thought put into them and both move and look as I'd imagined.Gameplay-wise the game is clever as it has an almost 'choose your own difficulty' with the shrine settings. By activating more idols  you gain bigger rewards but this in turn makes the game much more difficult. The use of the distillery also allows the player themselves to choose what bonuses they gain from levelling up making it so The Kid is completely customised to the player. The same goes with weapons; a range of melee and ranged weapons drop throughout the game which once again allows the player to play at their preferred style. This isn't something I'm used to seeing in games and it added to my enjoyment.As for the soundtrack... it's honestly one of my favourite soundtracks and I'm someone who doesn't download soundtracks too much. It fits the mood of the game perfectly and  helps to immerse you straight into the world of Bastion. There's not much else I can say but I can guarantee that at the very least you should be able to fall in love with the soundtrack even if the game isn't for yourself.The replay factor varies. I'm not the sort of person who'd play a game more than once yet I found myself playing Bastion for the second time through with the new gamemode I'd unlocked. As it allows you to carry over your stats and weapons from your previous save it makes the game a lot easier which some people may dislike but I enjoyed immensely. The game isn't so long that replaying it feels tedious either!Ultimately I ended up being surprised that this game was made by an indie developer as it's so polished and such a beautiful, engaging game. There's not much I can fault other than one slight disgruntlement with the storyline to be honest. This comes highly recommended if there's anyone else who hasn't played it, even when it's not on sale. If it's on sale... well, there's no excuse to not buy Bastion.

Posted: December 18, 2014
												A tremendous, perhaps even startling achievement, "Bastion" is everything great in gaming.It starts with a tremendously accessible and altogether fluid control system that works beautifully on PC. It adds to that a number of "micro-customizations" that let you nudge the core mechanics towards your favored playstyle. These micro-customizations take the form of weapons, weapon upgrades, "spirits" that act as passive skills, and shrine idols that make things tougher.On top of that, the game places very nicely crafted art. "Bastion's" visual stylings are highly distinctive, fun to look at, and also completely functional as a gameplay element.The final layer is a wrenching, yet never overdone or melodramatic story. There are very rich, mysterious elements that get woven in to fire up your imagination, and those elements are given with the same sensitivity and subtlety as the character arcs. The story is told almost entirely through gameplay, which keeps the narrative entirely connected to what's going on....and that soundtrack. Goodness gracious, that soundtrack. A person could buy this game for the sole purpose of listening to it. The music is superb (especially the main theme and the blues/ Americana tinged tracks) and the narrator could read a phone book without becoming tiresome.As far as I can tell, "Bastion" is flawless.

Posted: September 22, 2013
There's a short pro/con list at the end of this review, if you don't feel like reading this whole bunch of text.ReviewBastion is one of those games you just have to fall in love with 'cause it's incredibly intriguing from the very beginning.The story takes place in the fictional city of Caelondia and its surroundings, now fractured because of a catastrophe called the Calamity. The Calamity broke the world apart and turned nearly all its inhabitants to ash. Now, the pieces of this world float in the sky, and the Kid (the protagonist of the game) awakens on one of these pieces. He sets out to reach the Bastion, a place said to be safe in times of trouble.One of the many things I love about Bastion is how you build the world around you by exploring it. Your path forms in front of you as you fight your way through enemies and investigate the area. This, as well as the use of vivid colors, make the world feel very lively, despite the destruction the Calamity has brought upon Caelondia.Also, the soundtrack is amazing. Seriously, buy it, it's gold.Bastion is labeled as an action role-playing game, but I would specify that and call it a hack-and-slay game because of its focus on combat and variety of weapons (you're welcome to disagree with that point, but I think genres to be quite squishy anyway; Bastion just feels more like a hack-and-slay game to me). There we have another thing I love about this game: you can choose from plenty of weapons and combine them any way you want.There are 11 unique items, either melee or ranged weapons, and you can carry two at once. By default, you equip one melee and one ranged weapon, but you can replace them anytime at the Armory. You want to carry two melee weapons, for example your trusty Cael Hammer AND the War Machete? No problem. Two ranged weapons, let's say, the Scrap Musket in combination with the Breaker's Bow? Why not?The third equipment slot is reserved for Secret Skills you find, win, or buy later in the game.There are many more possibilities to customize your character, for example Spirits providing passive bonuses; let's just say, you can choose equipment from a REALLY great range of thingies.My favorite thing about Bastion, though, is the narrative style. The Kid himself is silent throughout the whole game, but there is a narrator whose voice accompanies the protagonist, providing the player with background information and reacting to what he or she chooses to do.The voice is so incredibly great; really calm but rough at the same time. It feels like it belongs to an older, experienced man who grew a little tired of all the stuff happening around him after years of turmoil - and I think that is perfect. You get the feeling that you're hanging out in a pub, and you meet an aged man who tells you stories about his life as a young adventurer. This may be the greatest thing about Bastion - that you feel like you get to know the narrator, like he personally speaks to you and no one else.All in all, I think Bastion might be one of the most beautiful games set in a post-apocalyptic world I've ever played. The art style and soundtrack go so well with the atmosphere, and the narrative style is breathtaking. The gameplay is really fun and allows for a lot of customization. I already recommend it to anyone who's into video games, and I don't think you would regret playing it.Short list for everyone who's too lazy to read this:• multiple endings• playtime (first run, didn't finish 100 % of the game) approx. 11 hoursPros:+ beautiful graphics+ amazing soundtrack+ 11 unique weapons (melee as well as ranged weapons), all upgradeable+ high customizability (e.g. weapons, Spirits, etc.)+ extraordinary narrative style+ stunning voice acting+ collectibles and side quests/challenges (e.g. mementos, proving grounds for each weapon, vigils)+ great control over difficulty level (you can activate up to 10 Idols, each making enemies stronger in some way and rewarding you with more XP and fragments in return; great system in my opinion)Cons:- New Game+ Mode doesn't offer anything too special

Posted: December 4, 2014
												Admittedly, I missed the Bastion hype train when it came chugging past in 2011 and had only ever heard of a brief description of it being 'good' from people around me. How I missed that goodness knows but after playing Bastion I can only say that it completely lives up to the hype around it.In an action RPG hack and slasher, you play as a character simply called The Kid. What unfolds is a story where there is no 'good' or 'bad' but instead a morally grey area for a majority of the characters which leads to some interesting perspectives. The story is told by the narrator who comments and narrates almost everything you do as The Kid. Perhaps people can see this as being a gimmick for the game but I personally found it delightfully charming and enjoyed listening to the commentary as I played. It helps to try the story forward and serves as encouragement if you should get stuck to keep going. The only gripe I have about the story is that I would've liked to have a bit more of it, plus one of the decisions that you're forced to choose at the end doesn't seem to have much of an effect on the end story.Graphically the game is stunning, even living up to the standards of 2014. Seeing the ground rise up around my character as I walked was stunning and helped to keep the pace of the game. Every area has been designed carefully so there's a lot to see and do in a story that is around 5 hours long. The foes you come up against have all had thought put into them and both move and look as I'd imagined.Gameplay-wise the game is clever as it has an almost 'choose your own difficulty' with the shrine settings. By activating more idols  you gain bigger rewards but this in turn makes the game much more difficult. The use of the distillery also allows the player themselves to choose what bonuses they gain from levelling up making it so The Kid is completely customised to the player. The same goes with weapons; a range of melee and ranged weapons drop throughout the game which once again allows the player to play at their preferred style. This isn't something I'm used to seeing in games and it added to my enjoyment.As for the soundtrack... it's honestly one of my favourite soundtracks and I'm someone who doesn't download soundtracks too much. It fits the mood of the game perfectly and  helps to immerse you straight into the world of Bastion. There's not much else I can say but I can guarantee that at the very least you should be able to fall in love with the soundtrack even if the game isn't for yourself.The replay factor varies. I'm not the sort of person who'd play a game more than once yet I found myself playing Bastion for the second time through with the new gamemode I'd unlocked. As it allows you to carry over your stats and weapons from your previous save it makes the game a lot easier which some people may dislike but I enjoyed immensely. The game isn't so long that replaying it feels tedious either!Ultimately I ended up being surprised that this game was made by an indie developer as it's so polished and such a beautiful, engaging game. There's not much I can fault other than one slight disgruntlement with the storyline to be honest. This comes highly recommended if there's anyone else who hasn't played it, even when it's not on sale. If it's on sale... well, there's no excuse to not buy Bastion.

												Played the game before, never got around to actually finishing till now.  Because of this I must rewrite my review:Bastion is an RPG that stands out from many other RPGs out there.  The path lays themselves down as you walk on them and the game itself is an art.  Fighting system is also not too complex but still offers various options for loadout and passive skills.  If the game is too easy, you can add additional challenges by invoking one (or all) of the ten gods available.  The narrator is one of the game's unique feature as he narrates everything you do - including your dumb mistakes.  But the best part of the game is the story itself. 												Where do I start with this game....?I will probably be just another person telling you to buy this game but seriously you should and I will tell you why.Lets start with the graphics....the aesthetic of Bastion is beautiful, colorful, and full of taste. Not only will Bastion's graphics hold up over time for years to come, not only should the gamer enjoy the aesthetic but the team at Supergiant Games should be proud of them. Some Gamers may disagree about the games graphics but what they can't do is ignore the amount of time, expression, and hard work that has gone into creating the world of Bastion.Gameplay remains to be the very core of all video games made. In this department Bastion shines with wonderful action and tones of a role playing game. Bastion will control a lot like a normal game using the WASD for movement and left/right clicking for attacks. Bastion also introduces other key strokes for abilities that make the gameplay not only fun but strategic on how to tackle your enemy. By introducing new weapons with different play styles Bastion remains fresh in changing it up not too often but just enough to give the player a taste of what a new weapon is and how to use it.Story....Where do I begin with this.....I have been playing games for a little over 20 years and can't recall off the top of my head a game that tells an amazing story in 3rd person in such a successful way as Bastion. I was not expecting this going into the game nor did I find it odd that the main character never has a voice out loud. The decisions you make will reflect the outcome of the game with a story powerful and demanding of me to finish my first playthrough within 2 days of starting! The game length is just long enough to enjoy and sink yourself into the world but not long enough to exclude the casual gamer or multiple playthroughs. Overall I had a great time with Bastion, if anyone asks me for a recommendation or directly asks me about Bastion I would not hesitate to offer my opinion. Supergiant Games you really outdid yourself on Bastion and have gained a loyal fan to the games you create. I hope to see more from this developer in the future of gaming. Posted: July 21, 2013
												Everyone already knows how great this game is, so I'm obviously going over familiar ground here, but if for some godforsaken reason you don't already own Bastion, fix that immediately!As an action game, Bastion not breaking new ground by any stretch.  It's a pretty simple little overhead beatemup that has you completing story and challenge missions in order to build up your hub, which in turn provides increased weapon variety and various RPG lite upgrade paths.  The gameplay isn't groundbreaking but it is certainly adequate.  The controls are tight and the weapons feel right.  There is also certain amount of tactical variety in terms of how you can deal with a given encounter, which provides both an incentive to upgrade different paths and an incentive to replay the game down the road.Where Bastion shines of course, is the atmostphere.  The main character, The Kid, has his story narrated by an incredible voice actor, and as you play through it you development an attachment to The Kid as well as to the characters around him.  There isn't a ton of depth in the story, but it is presented well, giving glimpses of the world that has broken apart, and when you have to finally make some tough choices later in the game, the existing emotional investment actually gives weight to those choices.The music / sound and art are also wonderful.As I said though, none of this is new. You probably already own this.  If you haven't played it, do.  If you don't, buy it, and do.Controller required though.

Posted: December 5, 2012
												Played the game before, never got around to actually finishing till now.  Because of this I must rewrite my review:Bastion is an RPG that stands out from many other RPGs out there.  The path lays themselves down as you walk on them and the game itself is an art.  Fighting system is also not too complex but still offers various options for loadout and passive skills.  If the game is too easy, you can add additional challenges by invoking one (or all) of the ten gods available.  The narrator is one of the game's unique feature as he narrates everything you do - including your dumb mistakes.  But the best part of the game is the story itself.  You start the game knowing nothing about yourself or the world or anyone.  But in time, the story will come together like a puzzle and the ending is definitely worth playing for.  In my opinion, it's one of the best endings I've seen.  It's not a long game - I finished it in 12 hours (and I took my sweet time).TL;DR: PLAY IT!Tip: if you have a controller, use it!  This game is so much better with a controller, in my opinion.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												Talking about the gameplay of this game is probably the easiest part:You have two weapons that you can choose from a pool of up to 12 (or something). New weapons get introduced regularly up to and including the final level. With the left and right mouse buttons you shoot, slash, smash, stab and/or pistol-sling things until they are dead. There are many different things to kill, which keeps up the variety nicely, and being able to dodge-roll like crazy keeps a steady and exciting pace.There are minor gripes (such as the lock-on being a bit imprecise at some points), but nothing even remotely gamebreaking.I may sound dismissive, but this is only because the hack'n'slash gameplay is merely good - compared to a narrative which is absolutely excellent.Bastion puts you into the shoes of The Kid, a tough lone survivor of an almost world-ending catastrophe called The Calamity. He quickly finds his way to a safe haven called The Bastion, but is disappointed to find only one survivor - Rucks, who is also the narrator of this game. Now you might have heard how this game has a "dynamic narrator" and the way it's been marketed is slightly less than truthful - the vast majority of the narrator's lines are scripted and occur at fixed points in the narrative. This doesn't matter one bit though, because there are many, many such lines and Logan Cunningham as Rucks manages to get every single one of them to work. This narrator is sometimes funny as hell, sometimes tough and cool, sometimes sad and wistful, sometimes something else entirely... but it works. It sucks you right into the world and doesn't let you go until you have heard the last of his incredibly well-written comments.To me, the narrator alone is a unique and overwhelming selling point, but that is not to say that this is the only way the narrative and the art of this game will charm you. Caelondia, the main setting of this game, is (as the above screenshots will verify) a colorful and beautiful and interesting and varied place. The range of levels (and related moods and tones and gameplay changes) is huge, though the way new locations keep getting introduced and then forgotten after a short visit may remind you of an overambitious sightseer with an overstuffed travel schedule.The music is excellent, moody and serene and exciting as the situation demands. Special mention should be reserved for two absolutely beautiful guitar-and-voice pieces that I won't spoil. Let me just say that they fit into the plot and have a lot more going for them than you would understand on a superficial hearing.Finally, I have to give the gameplay some more credit. That is, the way it merges at times with the plot to create... art.Sorry, that sounded horribly pretentious, but it really is the only word I can find for it. Supergiant Games have somehow managed to make the simplistic and violent mechanics of hack'n'slash appear meaningful in a story about loss and recovery, desperation and hope.... god damn it, there comes the pretension again.Let me just finish this paragraph by saying that one possible endgame scenario is the capital B Best synergy of engaging gameplay and poignant storytelling that I have ever seen or could ever imagine.In closing, Bastion remains one of my favorite games of all times. This is very much an "art" game in the sense that you get the feeling the people working on it wanted to make something beautiful and something that really resonates with people. And they succeeded. As a little extra, I'd like to note that the narrator has an unique comment for every possible combination of weapons. Sometimes it adds a little extra texture to the world, sometimes commenting on the style of fighting it implies. Wow. (All possible combinations of two weapons from a pool of 10 = 45, if my calculations are correct. Anyway, you get my point.)

Posted: December 13, 2014
												By this point Bastion doesn't need another positive review to solidify its standing as a must have game. With only the most bitter and caustic contrarians providing negative feedback, Bastion has an approval rate of 98%. That should speak highly of the game's value but one should always strive to understand what makes something good rather than blindly following popular opinion like one more lemming in the heard and indeed one should highlight the strengths of a thing rather than simply using popular opinion to define something's value. Rest assured however, in this case, Bastion is one cliff you'll be happy to jump off of with the rest of us.Bastion begins with a young child waking up to find his world falling apart, literally. An ominous and mysterious disaster, referred to as the Calamity, has caused the fabric of the world to collapse. Finding that only he and one other person survived, the boy must recollect the essence of the world and rebuild it. Narrated by one of the best voices on planet Earth, the boy's journey takes him through the ruins of a deep and interesting setting. Indeed Bastion has one of the most unique settings in video games, its indie origins contributing to the bravery of doing something new and interesting. The game is fairly short admittedly and to discuss too much of the plot would be to give it away but trust me in that it doesn't disappoint.Mechanically the game is remarkably solid. The purpose of collecting the shards and mcguffins is to upgrade both your base and character. There are a wide variety of weapons and enough distinction between bonuses and weapons to fit a wide variety of play styles. Being of a short length, the difficulty ramps up quickly and you must choose which upgrades are most valuable to your play style. Committing is the crux of the matter as your investments need to pay off to complete later levels.With story and mechanics blended this well, I never stopped feeling engaged. My drive maintained from start to finish which is tougher that one might think. Bastion walks a very fine line with not having any lulls in the action while at the same time not being overwhelming about it. My final analysis: Buy this game. It is great.

Posted: February 23, 2015
												+ Tons of atmosphere+ Great soundtrack+ Great voice work by the narrator+ Art and visual aesthetic- Not a lot of depth in combat or other gameplay features.I've played through Bastion twice now and it's still very enjoyable.  One can't really say enough about the great job Supergiant did with building an interesting and slightly mysterious world, and crammed it with atmosphere and character.  Everything from the music, the narration, the detailed and beautiful art, and interesting plot all add up to a world you like seeing and experiencing.  The music and voicework really deserve their own mention, winning many awards (not that those mean much nowadays) for both the composer and Logan Cunningham for his portrayal as the Narrator.  The best way I can describe the soundtrack is like...acoustic frontier western folk music mixed with electronica.  It's great and can easily be listened to on it's own.  The games combat mechanics are the one thing that doesn't shine quite as bright as the rest.  What is there is very solid and controls just fine, but it tends to be a bit dull and not very challenging, especially in the first half or so of the game.  It gets a bit button mashy.  Later on, more enemies and more varied weapons and projectiles pick up the pace and things feel much better.  I just wish I had the same level of enjoyment in combat throughout all of it.  There are some city building and weapon upgrade features, which are welcome, but don't have much substance.  With more time and money in the budget, I'd love to see what Supergiant can do with a more fleshed out sequel.It's the atmosphere and aesthetics that take this good game and elevate it to something special.

Posted: November 19, 2015
												After 16.116 reviews, there's nothing else to say about this game right? Wrong.Everybody feels this game differently, that's one of its assets, but some things just never change. There are some mechanics that are not explained in the game at all and I for one would have liked to know 'em before I started playing. Hence this little reviewlike walkthrough of mine came to be:First, I'd like to say you won't regret buying this game. But you already knew that, didn't you?After all, Bastion is a really fun game, Aciton RPG oriented, with a somewhat limited combat system that wil♥♥♥♥♥♥you off from time to time but don't worry. You'll get it eventually!Where was I? Oh, right...Instead of talking about the strong suits of the game, I'd like to talk about it's flaws. 'Cause yes. It's got them.Above all, I'd say there are two ways to play Bastion. Casual or Completionist.If you're heading for casual, congratulations! This game's made for you. Most levels don't last more than ten minutes and there's a specific game mode meant for you called "painless mode".However, if you intend to get everything in this game I must warn you. It won't be easy...Know this. You're gonna have to beat the game at least twice.Enjoy your fisrt playthrough, learn the paths, try out different weapons, smash Scumbags, feel the music and try to understad what the hell's going on. Don't worry yourself about challenges and leave the Idols for later. Just enjoy!Eventually, you'll reach the grand finale and will need to face a story changing decission. To get all the achievements you need to play both scenarios, so just pick whatever you feel like and enjoy the show. Both decissions will allow you to keep playing so don't worry yourself unnecesarily. Alas, the game feels like the best options are: 1st) Left - Left.2nd) Right - Right.One down, one to go. Once you complete the stoy for the first time, you'll unlock "New Game +" mode and "Score Attack" mode. You should know that the latter counts as a New Game + for the "Calamity Kid" achievement, so there's no real need to play the NG+ mode. The second playthrough's where you'll have to give your best. Start off with no less than five Idols to get the higuest amount of money and experience possible, finish the remaining challenges and enjoy your new traits. Another special move will be unlocked in the Armory (you don't need to own Portal to get it) and the History books in the Bastion will now lead you to a brand new "Who Knows Where" battle arena.Don't push it. Battle arenas can be "easily" beaten with your mortar and pike fully upgraded. But it will take some time to complete the arenas. Strategy is key, choose the right tonics to aid you and take advantage of your surroundings.In addition, since you should already be playing in "Score Attack" mode, you can get the "Hard bargain" achievement as well. It is not an easy achevement to get, but a valid method to obtain it has already been discovered. Advance in the story until you unlock the Pipe, then equip "Black Rye" and "Whale Ale" choose a long and short range weapon in the armory, equip the "Gel Cannister" as your special move and renounce "Acobi", "Roathus" and "Olak" at the Temple leaving the remaining Idols active. All you have to do now is enter the Kid's Dream and try to keep the chain with your turrets. Have fun!!After a while, you should get all the remaining achievements. Thus concluding the completionist path. Congratulations, you did it!!!Now, regardless of the path you've chosen to enjoy this game, the experience is definitely worth it, but for he completionist gamers it feels like it is a bit harder than it should be unlike what happens in Transistor for example, the next game you should be cheking on! (^_^)

Posted: December 24, 2013
												Bastion is a good game ... but not a great one.  Lets get to the good stuff first.  The first thing most people will mention is the narrator and with good reason.  Everything you do in Bastion is narrated.  Whether you are fighting monsters, buying upgrades, or just standing around, the narrator always has something relavent to say.  The voice actor has a great voice for the part and he helps make something that could have been gimicy a stand out feature of the game.The art and look of the game are excellent.  Vivid colors, unique art design and locals, and a cartoony look make the game look and feel unique.  When you aren't being attacked just wondering through the different locations is a treat.  New enemies, new upgradable weapons, dreams (arenas), and boss fights keep the game feeling fresh.  Getting stuck at a certain spot, find the location to upgrade one of your weapons and go through the trial there to see if you unlock new items and upgrades.  The dreams are a good places to rack up money and face a good challenge as combinations of enemies attack you in different rounds.  The music is simple but effective.  It never gets overly complicated or stands out, it just accompanies game play and it does that well.  It may not be for everyone but I enjoyed it.The control scheme with a keyboard and mouse was a little cumbersome.  It felt hard to be precise with my movements using the WASD for my movement keys.  The mouse gave me good accuracy for targeting but given a choice I think the game would feel better being played on a controller.While it was fun upgrading my weapons, I would have liked to have ablities to unlock or upgrade on my character that would make combat even more fun and varied.  This could have lived up some of the boss fights which devolved into run far away as possible and use a missile weapon, rinse, repeat.The very end isn't a traditional boss fight.  I won't spoil it here and some may have been put off by it but I liked how it finished the story and did something other then kill the boss, roll credits.  I would recommend this game for most people to try out.  Watch the videos and if you are intrigued give it a try, I don't think you will be disappointed.

Posted: August 14, 2014
												Before I actaully go into any sort of depth, for anyone that uses the Steam reviews of a game in the same way that I do, the game functions!  Some people have complained about the keyboard & mouse controls, but the controls were perfectly fine on a 360 controller.  Now, onto the review proper.Bastion is a game where a mysterious calamity (simply called "The Calamity" by survivors) has wiped out most of the world's population and shot most of the land into the air.  You play as a boy (simply called "The Kid"), and must traverse various different locations to find Cores, magical crystals that will help to rebuild The Bastion.  One of the first things that people will notice about the game is the unique way that the narrative is framed.  Many of the different things that you do in the game are accompanied by a narration.  The voice actor perfectly fits the Steampunk/western style of the game, and is an absolute joy to listen to, even though he is the only voice actor in the game (aside from a few of the songs that contain lyrics and a small amount of dialogue with another character at the end).  The narration is meant to be one of the characters in the game retelling of past events, occasionally foreshadowing something or giving his personal thoughts.  The game allows you to find out about the lore of the game and the backstories of the characters as if you were actually the person listening to the story, allowing for you to decide what is true and what is made up.  Additionally, the beautiful handpainted graphics add to the atmosphere of the game in an incredible way.  You may end up feeling as if you don't want to kill any of the monsters, since they look so interesting, but avoiding them is generally not an option.  The game also explicitly mentions that many of the creatures used to be docile before The Calamity, leaving it up to the player why they suddenly want to kill The Kid (at one point, the narrator even says "At first they left the barge alone, then they saw who was riding it.").Style can only account for a part of the experience of playing a game, though, so onto the gameplay.  The game has a sort of hack-and-slash style to it, and can feel very satisfying.  The weapons are all nicely varied, allowing for many different choices, and, in addition, each combination of two weapons elicits a unique line from the narrator.  The weapon upgrading system, featuring the ability to switch between 2 paths (usually representing effects versus damage), and its feature of allowing the player to mix and match upgrades at a will, adds even more depth.  Despite feeling satisfactory, the combat can feel a bit too easy once you get the hang of it, but learning each weapon as more are introduced throughout the game is great.  The "Proving Grounds," of which there is one for each weapon, however, are a very nice challenge for the most part, and completing all of them is very rewarding, even if you as the player don't like to use the weapon that it's relating to.  The spirits that can upgrade your stats are a nice touch too, being a very unique way of upgrading and, again, eliciting a unique line of dialogue from the narrator whenever one is equipped, usually talking about its Pre-Calamity use or reputation.Of course, since the soundtrack of this game is so famous, I would be remiss to review it without mentioning the music.  The soundtrack in this game is possibly the best I've ever heard.  The area tracks fit perfectly with whatever kind of atmosphere that area wants to convey.  The musical cues are spot-on, and the few previously mentioned tracks (entitled "Build That Wall"; "Mother I'm Here"; and "Setting Sail, Coming Home," respectively) are indescribably wonderful.  Even while typing out this review, I'm listening to the soundtrack in the background.  It's THAT good, and I'd say definitely worth a look, even if you don't plan on playing the game.On release, this game recieved major critical acclaim.  I have to say that, even though I only ever played it 3 years later, the game is wholly deserving of any and all praise.  It has, very occasionally, been accused of pretentiousness, and, to this, I have to say that a game being "artsy" and it being "pretentious" are two very different things.  The handpainted backgrounds and incredible score add a level of atmosphere rarely seen in games.  The gameplay is very satisfying and rewarding, and there was a moment in the story, close to the end, that genuinely made me, a person who tries to keep my emotions to myself, burst into tears.  I won't spoil it by saying what it is, but what I can say about it is that it's one of the most emotional and well set up moments I've ever seen in anything.  I don't really know what I can add to the discussion about this game, as I'm sure that all I've said has been said elsewhere by other people, but, if you've read this far, all I can say is that this is a game worth getting.  Anyone who can appreciate games as an artform owes it to themselves to play this game.  It's fun, it's emotional, it's amazing.

												Bastion is a good game, make no mistake, but it's considerable style outweighs its substance. It's certainly a beautiful game, the hand-drawn art style graphics are very pretty and distinctive, fitting well with the general tone, although they can sometimes get a little busy. There were also times where the isometric viewpoint combined with some strange shapes made the safe pathway a little less than obvious. Visually, it's a treat from beginning to end.The soundtrack, in my opinion, is the Bastion's strongest asset. The score is wonderful, taking old-western guitar twang and mixing it beautifully with other velvety tones that make the soundtrack bundle worth the extra dough. The narration is also great, adding a new and interesting way of framing the story and directing the player with a voice that sounds like molten caramel. The story it frames is also fairly good, if a little bewildering to start with.On the downside, the actual gameplay is fairly homogenous. Most of the game consists of "go to a place, hack and slash until everything is dead, grab a magical something-or-other and flee before the ground disappears from under you" on a repeating cycle.  The variety of weapons and special attacks and the challenges offered by the Shrines (difficulty-boosting optional extras) and other challenges offer a little bit of variety, but I can't see myself making use of the New Game Plus feature. Despite there being two possible endings, I just didn't enjoy the 5 hours I spent with it enough to want to go back any time soon.Overall though, considering I paid quite a lot less than the list price for Bastion, I still got my money's worth and would recommend it to anyone who doesn't mind beauty being mostly skin deep.

												Bastion is a good game ... but not a great one.  Lets get to the good stuff first.  The first thing most people will mention is the narrator and with good reason.  Everything you do in Bastion is narrated.  Whether you are fighting monsters, buying upgrades, or just standing around, the narrator always has something relavent to say.  The voice actor has a great voice for the part and he helps make something that could have been gimicy a stand out feature of the game.The art and look of the game are excellent.  Vivid colors, unique art design and locals, and a cartoony look make the game look and feel unique.  When you aren't being attacked just wondering through the different locations is a treat.  New enemies, new upgradable weapons, dreams (arenas), and boss fights keep the game feeling fresh.  Getting stuck at a certain spot, find the location to upgrade one of your weapons and go through the trial there to see if you unlock new items and upgrades.  The dreams are a good places to rack up money and face a good challenge as combinations of enemies attack you in different rounds.  The music is simple but effective.  It never gets overly complicated or stands out, it just accompanies game play and it does that well.  It may not be for everyone but I enjoyed it.The control scheme with a keyboard and mouse was a little cumbersome.  It felt hard to be precise with my movements using the WASD for my movement keys.  The mouse gave me good accuracy for targeting but given a choice I think the game would feel better being played on a controller.While it was fun upgrading my weapons, I would have liked to have ablities to unlock or upgrade on my character that would make combat even more fun and varied.  This could have lived up some of the boss fights which devolved into run far away as possible and use a missile weapon, rinse, repeat.The very end isn't a traditional boss fight.  I won't spoil it here and some may have been put off by it but I liked how it finished the story and did something other then kill the boss, roll credits.  I would recommend this game for most people to try out.  Watch the videos and if you are intrigued give it a try, I don't think you will be disappointed.

Posted: March 10, 2013
												This is one of very few action RPGs with a compelling story and good characters. If compelling stories and good characters are what you're looking for, play it. It's good. It's really good.It's not a stereotypical action RPG either. You start with your character waking up in his bed with all the world except the 10-foot radius around him just gone. When you walk, the world floats up and pieces itself back together in front of you. It's not only a cool visual effect. It's also part of the story's worldbuilding and a metaphor for the main character trying to piece his life back together after a catastrophic event that evidently left the world wiped out.Gameplay-wise, the action is skillful and fast -- much more skillful and much faster than I could handle at higher difficulties (note: difficulty levels are built into the game's lore, so that's pretty cool too). It's also fun and responsive, though the isometric perspective combined with the colorful levels and masses of objects and enemies alike moving around the screen at once, it can get confusing. It's never so confusing that it becomes unplayable, though. It just starts to feel a little like a bullet-hell shooter at times, and it's not even a shooter.The music's not getting out of here without a mention. I got the soundtrack in one of the Humble Bundles, and I've listened to it far more than any other video game soundtrack (except perhaps Metal Gear). It has an electro-western feel to it that's a bit difficult to describe. The lead acoustic guitar is tuned down to something odd that I tried out on my own guitar (note: just a simple open strum sounds cool in the tuning Bastion's music uses). There are vocals in a few of the songs, and they all come in at exactly the right time for the meaning of the song and the context in which they're played to punch you right in the feels. Sometimes, the music fits so well (mostly the instrumental stuff) that I didn't even realize it was there. It's incredibly unique for a game in the fantasy genre, and the same could be said of all the game's design, from art to writing to music and even to gameplay to an extent.Each weapon feels different and serves a different playstyle, which is more than can be said for nearly any other game in Bastion's genre. The Cael hammer, the default weapon and the one I used throughout nearly the whole game, feels like it has weight and power packed in every swing. The sword is quick and slicey, the guns are suitably punchy, and the bow is precise enough to feel great.If you thought Diablo was the king of the action RPG genre (any of the three), I request you try Bastion. At least in my opinion, it completely demolishes all three Diablo games in every area on which it contends (Bastion has no loot system, so there's no contest there): story, characters, art style, music, worldbuilding, combat, and probably a few I missed.Play Bastion. You'll be doing yourself a favor.

Posted: July 13, 2016
												A quick TL;DR, if you're buying the game on the spot; the interface is good, the story is interesting, the combat system is fun, just buy it if you're into the genre.The Interface is surprisingly user friendly. It's compatible with all sorts of things, from controllers to your plain mouse and keyboard. They're all pretty intuitive and easy to learn, so you'll get used to the controls quickly. It's also got your usual subtitles and your audio settings. You can have different profiles, which allows you to start over from scratch without destroying your perfect save. Tons of resolution options, too. Generally pretty solid.The story is pretty vague at first; you're a kid, well, you're The Kid, you wake up on a floating island miles away from sea level due to some apocalyptic event, and an omnipresent narrator voice is talking to you, describing your every move. I'd rather not go any further with the story (and you've heard this tons of times. Believe me, I also get tired of hearing this, but this is for real): you should experience it yourself. Supergiant prides itself on digging out lore out of seemingly nothing, it's practically a talent. This game has amazing replayability and you can easily get lost just slashing through everything. The game includes idols that will rise the stakes if you find it too easy. Oh, and the combat system? Love it. I'm biased, since I love hack and slash games, but this game features a diverse cast of weapons that you can mod for extra perks, letting you cherrypick your favorite perks. Will you go for extra damage, or settle for a higher critical chance? Besides weapons, you can drink spirits that will give you passive perks, from extra resistance to retaliating damage.There's not much that I can say about the artwork that hasn't been said. All of the art for the game is very impressive and, to top, very fitting. To close this, since we're talking about art, there's a reason the game is tagged with great soundtrack. The music is also very unique, the artist even giving it its own name (I seriously cannot remember what he called it, but it was a mouthful). Adds a lot of character to the game.Buy it. At best, you'll love it and play it again, and again, and again (or not, it's a 6-11 hour long game), at worst you'll play it once and be kind of okay about it. But if you're bent on getting all those achievements, you will clock out more hours than that. Just go play it. It's art.

Posted: December 23, 2013
												Where to begin? This game is absolutley beautiful, from the soundtrack, to the different regions/"worlds", the art style, the very vibe it gives off; it is amazing. There is something so mystical and vibrant about the environment that I just can't put my finger on. The Narrator's voice also adds a lot to the game; he is the one who walks you through vivid memories and reflections of the characters in the game, and without hardly any clips or unskippable sequences to accompany it. No other speaking voice besides the Narrator's is used, and I honestly wouldn't have it any other way; his descriptions and story-telling is really all you need, and adds to the feel of the game in a very positive way.The story of the game itself feels fresh, and is very interesting if you can keep up with listening to the Narrator while trying to fight your way through intense enemy sequences, which is my only real gripe. Then again, its best to save time and works more fluidly for him to explain while you are fighting in the area he is explaining. If you want to know the fine details of the story, you really can't afford to zone out for too long, because he describes things in simple sentences (that do the job and do it fantastically), but make it all the more harder to refocus and understand what just happened.The gameplay is very smooth and just works. No complaints there. As you travel through each region, the ground literally places itself piece by piece out in front of you, adding to the beauty and mystical vibe of the game. I love all the different weapons and skills you can equip and upgrade to use in battle; it makes everything more diverse and suitable to your playing style, which is kind of a standard for an RPG, but the game has its unique twist all the same. A drawback is that if you die, you have to start that region/level all over instead of having a checkpoint to teleport to. The enemies are varied, but they seem to have the same themes depending on which part of the game you are in and/or what region/level you are playing. They are not too difficult to defeat, but you can make it more challenging by using Divine Idols which can make enemies more resistant to attacks, hit harder, etc.Overall, this game is simply gorgeous and all-around fantastic, involving some of the best art styles, music, and usage of a Narrator I've ever seen. I would definitley reccomend to anyone who wants a great adventure with a good story.

												The soundtrack! Just the soundtrack! It's possibly the best thing about this game. I have spent a good time just in the main menu listening to that guitar track.The world of Bastion is a wonderful world, there is nothing like it that I know of. All the little things like the skyway travel system in the hub or the fact you don't just have "Special abilities" you have black tonics. The Bastion itself and the characters are just wonderful and add to the world. The artistic design of the whole world is very different but also very good such as how the floor appears and builds itself underneath you as you walk. The game itself is not a massive graphically demanding shiney game like Crysis but it still looks lovely due to the art and aesthetic.The combat is kind of simple but is fine tuned and very skilful. You rely on your skill in fighting and dodging to win, just spamming the attack button won't work. The upgrades is very much the same, it's simple but effective. None of the weapons become over powered by any upgrades, they are merely just your personal play style. Do you want to use the great big two handed Cael Hammer or use the fast shooting and nimble Fanged Repeater?The story is a bit grim, taking place after what is just called "The Calamity" which you are slowly fed information about along with the rest of the background story but it is done so well. This is due to the narrator who is possibly the best voiced and best paced narrator I have ever heard besides maybe Thomas Was Alone. It is done so well i would recommend the game purely for that. But thankfully Bastion is great is every regard and so i can recommend it for everything. Which I do.

Posted: January 8, 2014
												The Facts~Game rating based on the ESRB: E (Everyone)Single-PlayerPlatforms: Microsoft Windows, Mac OS C, XBox 360, iOS, GoogleChrome, Linux, OnLive.Developer: Supergiant Games.Genre: Action Role-playing.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Plot-A great calamity has struck the world, and you, a lone kid has to find out why and how to fix it. You travel through the world searching for various items to restore the Bastion and to find what survivors that you can. Challenging foes and exploring what is left of the world until you finally find what you can to prevail.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Character Design-Playing through you will find that at the start, you didn't know anything about the characters, as few as there are. Through the gameplay you will find out more and more, who they were before the story began, and how it was changing them. It doesn't stop there either. Characters that have no place in the game yet were every bit as significant in the past come into play and you get to know a little about them and how they fit into the world that once was.Through the telling of the characters you will begin to feel a bit attached and even befriend the narrator through all the story.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Music & Artwork-This is where the game hits a home run in full, with music playing constantly in the background of gameplay it adds for a wonderful aura to the game, you are never left to feel alone and it is always a mellow tempo until a fight ensues, and then it picks up pace a tad. The sounds the emit from battle are flawless and the narration is one of my favorite details.The artwork is suburb, the coloration style and way the world literally builds itself before your very eyes is uncanny. It truly makes you feel more in tune with exploring. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Gameplay-The controls are actually incredibly smooth for an indie game, I was very impressed. There is not much to be said other than that.Customization was a large feature in building the bastion and even in picking what weapons and special ability you wanted to have by your side in the heat of a battle.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Conclusion-All in all, after getting this game, I learned never to judge a game before I play it again. This was a fantastic game and I am proud to own it. With all this said I proudly give Bastion a 10/10 with a 8.5/10 replay value.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The game hits you hard with major challenges early on, and steadily ramps up the difficulty while also providing a lot of new weapons and concepts to the player steadily. Posted: December 4, 2014
												Admittedly, I missed the Bastion hype train when it came chugging past in 2011 and had only ever heard of a brief description of it being 'good' from people around me. How I missed that goodness knows but after playing Bastion I can only say that it completely lives up to the hype around it.In an action RPG hack and slasher, you play as a character simply called The Kid. What unfolds is a story where there is no 'good' or 'bad' but instead a morally grey area for a majority of the characters which leads to some interesting perspectives. The story is told by the narrator who comments and narrates almost everything you do as The Kid. Perhaps people can see this as being a gimmick for the game but I personally found it delightfully charming and enjoyed listening to the commentary as I played. It helps to try the story forward and serves as encouragement if you should get stuck to keep going. The only gripe I have about the story is that I would've liked to have a bit more of it, plus one of the decisions that you're forced to choose at the end doesn't seem to have much of an effect on the end story.Graphically the game is stunning, even living up to the standards of 2014. Seeing the ground rise up around my character as I walked was stunning and helped to keep the pace of the game. Every area has been designed carefully so there's a lot to see and do in a story that is around 5 hours long. The foes you come up against have all had thought put into them and both move and look as I'd imagined.Gameplay-wise the game is clever as it has an almost 'choose your own difficulty' with the shrine settings. By activating more idols  you gain bigger rewards but this in turn makes the game much more difficult. The use of the distillery also allows the player themselves to choose what bonuses they gain from levelling up making it so The Kid is completely customised to the player. The same goes with weapons; a range of melee and ranged weapons drop throughout the game which once again allows the player to play at their preferred style. This isn't something I'm used to seeing in games and it added to my enjoyment.As for the soundtrack... it's honestly one of my favourite soundtracks and I'm someone who doesn't download soundtracks too much. It fits the mood of the game perfectly and  helps to immerse you straight into the world of Bastion. There's not much else I can say but I can guarantee that at the very least you should be able to fall in love with the soundtrack even if the game isn't for yourself.The replay factor varies. I'm not the sort of person who'd play a game more than once yet I found myself playing Bastion for the second time through with the new gamemode I'd unlocked. As it allows you to carry over your stats and weapons from your previous save it makes the game a lot easier which some people may dislike but I enjoyed immensely. The game isn't so long that replaying it feels tedious either!Ultimately I ended up being surprised that this game was made by an indie developer as it's so polished and such a beautiful, engaging game. There's not much I can fault other than one slight disgruntlement with the storyline to be honest. This comes highly recommended if there's anyone else who hasn't played it, even when it's not on sale. If it's on sale... well, there's no excuse to not buy Bastion.

Bastion is the debut game from independent developer Supergiant Games, and what a debut.  Bastion is an Action Role-Playing Game with beautiful art-style and music. It has an intriguing and different story narrated to you by a Stranger, which is one of the most recognizable features of the game. The gameplay and character's skills are solid, flexible and fun to mess around with. The game lends itself to at least 2 play-through’s with 2 different endings, but such is not mandatory to understand the story. One run should take you around 11 hours with the extra challenges. It has a Metacritic score of 86 (critics) and a 8.6 (users) . Overall, I really liked and had fun with the game, if you like action games and RPG’s I would recommend this game. I also think this could appeal to bullet hell shooter fans, because it has some elements of it although in a smaller scale.My Score: 9/10

Posted: June 27, 2014
												Short version: It's a good game with an awesome atmosphere and audio. Honestly it's too good to be an indie game and for it's price I'd definitely recommend buying it especially if it's on sale.What is Bastion? Well for me it was not only a game, but also an experience like Journey, Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons and other similar games. An experience that I will always remember.The gameplay is pretty simple: you move around the isometric maps and kill enemies and occasional bosses using a variety of melee and long range weapons. A more interesting twist is that later on you can set difficulty level you want by activating up to ten shrines that give various buffs to your enemies. Playing certain levels with all of the shrines active can be quite challenging. There is also a "New Game+" option when you finish the game and since it has multiple ending it can be worth having second playthrough.The visuals are very nice. Each level is beautifully drawn and the level builds up under your feet as you move which makes the overall look even more appealing. The sounds. There are two sides worth mentioning. The music and the Stranger. The music is really good and fits the game great. I'd probably think about buying it if I hadn't gotten it together with Bastion in the Humble Bundle. The Stranger is this games most known feature. He is the narrator that talks about you and your journey with a deep and very nice voice. He is so popular they even made a Bastion announcer for Dota 2.All in all this game will probably leave a lasting memory and is a great experience. I have really enjoyed playing it and it's definitely worth it's price. I would definitely recommend you to try Bastion. You will not regret it.

												Bastion is a strange game best known for it's narrator which is more like a commentator but is done so well that you never get annoyed by him repeating itself.The art is amazing as the ground raises from the bottom of the screen so you can walk on which makes exploring and finding secrets very rewarding. The general appearance of the levels and characters is very well done and thought out. Though I diddnt like the isometric type of view I wasnt punished by falling off the edge with a loss of life, the isometric view gives you the gods eye view which obviously works well with the narrator.The combat got repetitive but it was challenging you are able to block and use melee and ranged weapons. There are multiple weapons and you are able to customize your character even to suit the style you want such as using an arrow and a blunderbuss or 2 different melee weapons, or the 1 melee weapon and 1 ranged weapon. But you will always have a shield in Bastion which does resemble an old shoot em up at times.Bastion has a lot of life with it's replayability, the god shrine is a great idea, letting the enemy get stronger and getting more experience is a great idea. I finished the game and was given the option to play through it again but with all the unlocks available so its a great game for the completionists out there.Though I do believe it is overrated just a bit it obviously gets a lot of attention because of the narrator. If you like a challenge and good game design play!

Posted: December 13, 2014
												By this point Bastion doesn't need another positive review to solidify its standing as a must have game. With only the most bitter and caustic contrarians providing negative feedback, Bastion has an approval rate of 98%. That should speak highly of the game's value but one should always strive to understand what makes something good rather than blindly following popular opinion like one more lemming in the heard and indeed one should highlight the strengths of a thing rather than simply using popular opinion to define something's value. Rest assured however, in this case, Bastion is one cliff you'll be happy to jump off of with the rest of us.Bastion begins with a young child waking up to find his world falling apart, literally. An ominous and mysterious disaster, referred to as the Calamity, has caused the fabric of the world to collapse. Finding that only he and one other person survived, the boy must recollect the essence of the world and rebuild it. Narrated by one of the best voices on planet Earth, the boy's journey takes him through the ruins of a deep and interesting setting. Indeed Bastion has one of the most unique settings in video games, its indie origins contributing to the bravery of doing something new and interesting. The game is fairly short admittedly and to discuss too much of the plot would be to give it away but trust me in that it doesn't disappoint.Mechanically the game is remarkably solid. The purpose of collecting the shards and mcguffins is to upgrade both your base and character. There are a wide variety of weapons and enough distinction between bonuses and weapons to fit a wide variety of play styles. Being of a short length, the difficulty ramps up quickly and you must choose which upgrades are most valuable to your play style. Committing is the crux of the matter as your investments need to pay off to complete later levels.With story and mechanics blended this well, I never stopped feeling engaged. My drive maintained from start to finish which is tougher that one might think. Posted: March 23, 2016
												If you like a good soundtrack, character customization, art style and narration then you’ll be loving every second Bastion has to offer. Bastion is an hack and slash action RPG that combines an amazing art style with an even more amazing soundtrack. The combat and movement feels smooth and unique. There is a variety of different weapons that allows you to fight enemies the way you want. One of the best things about Bastion is the freshness of the game, there aren't many games that are able to pull of an amazing art style, soundtrack, narration and combat all at the same time. The scenery never gets boring and is alway changing with lots of minor details. One of the ways they do this is by having the ground around you form as you walk near it. This can help keep people with low attention spans to keep engaged with the game.The constant improvements to your character and weapons gives a lot more replayability to the game. Leveling up allows you to quipt a buffing effect called a ‘spirit’ to your character. Weapons can be upgraded through finding materials when exploring the world. Idols make the game harder in certain aspects and are used to give the player more of a challenge, this helps give the game more replayability. The hack and slash gameplay is well made with lots of different ways to defeat your enemies. Upgrading weapons was very satisfying and fun to do. Bastion's soundtrack is very good and interesting and can be what keeps some people playing the game. The art style is also very unique and fitting with the soundtrack.One of the cons the game has (And it’s hard to come across cons in Bastion) is that the hack and slash gameplay at times can get a little repetitive. It’s also lacking in a filled in story, for example It doesn’t talk about what the world was like before the calamity, leaving the world feeling a bit empty at times. The story missions are basic and revolve around collecting one sort of object for almost every mission. But these don’t make Bastion a bad game, far from it. These are just little things I found when playing Bastion other people might and probably do disagree with.On average Bastion takes around six and a half hours to complete the story, while to complete the story and all extras takes around twenty hours. Bastion keeps the story nice and short for players looking for a short and sweet experience, while giving the game a good amount of completion hours for those wanting to spend a good extra fifteen or so hours on the game. With this and everything I’ve covered I’d recommend this game to anyone who loves good hack and slash mechanics, art and soundtrack in the games they play. I think It’s well worth the full price of fifteen dollars, but if you find it on sale it’s a must buy.

Posted: December 28, 2011
												A brilliant story to get lost in.The vaguely Zen-like and mysterious atmosphere will keep you spellbound until the end - I was transported back to the days of being a kid playing Super Mario 3 and The Legend of Zelda on the NES way back when - not from a gameplay perspective, but in the sense that my imagination was utterly captured from start to finish. Through the game's music, its gradual explanatory narrative and the colorful, dream-scape art direction used in creating the enviroments and everything in them - this pervading sense of sadness and loss creeps in on your psyche and leaves a lasting impression.Then it does one better:Many games have allowed me to exist in a post cataclysmic world - few, if any, have made me care about understanding why and how the world ended. Levels assemble themselves from nothingness as you walk through them, and the narrative stitches places, people and events of old together into a grand tapestry. It takes time to begin to make sense. Your actions, while pre-determined in most cases, feel as if they have real weight and truly affect the future of everyone involved with your character.You play as 'The Kid'- an apt bit of vaguness that, through the fact that the protagonist utters nary a word out loud throughout the entire ordeal and all of his decisions made in game are in the player's hands, make the game a very personal experience. At no point did I feel like I was simply along for the ride. Without trying to give too much away, in Bastion you will eventually have to make your mind up and act on a very philosophically 'grey' course of action. There is none of the clear cut 'Hero or Villain of the Wastelands' duality going on here - both outcomes are potentially horrifying when thought about.The game is beautiful in a classical sense. It's isometric, with detailed backdrops all having a 'hand-crafted' feel - every level looks like it would be right at home painted on a canvas and hung above someone's fireplace. The music deserves an honorable mention as well. While it ticks all the right boxes, being wonderfully produced and ranging from up-beat and inspiring to melancholy and nostalgic, it is, through and through, just wonderful to listen to and completely suited to what you see on-screen. From experience, many devs do not seem to have a terribly hard time tying a soundtrack and visual elements together into something that 'works'. Sometimes, though, a title comes along and you just know that without that specific soundtrack that seems to reflect the involved themes so intrinsically, the game itself would have only been half the experience. Off the top of my head, Soul Reaver and the first Unreal are good examples of this.At the most basic level, it controls similarly to an ARPG akin to Diablo and Torchlight, but it stands completely apart from titles like these in its style and execution. Nox would be a closer comparison - less focus on stats and combat and more on the experience of existing in another world (I miss you, Westwood). You gain access to a few, upgradeable weapons, but at no point does that seem to be the focus. They are each fun and unique- no endless slew of samey implements with rainbow themed tiers of quality. Sorry grinders. Story and experience are what is important here. Personally speaking, I feel the greatest value of Bastion is in what your mind takes away from it. If you have any capacity for empathy, I can almost guarantee that you will dwell on everything that happened well after the credits have rolled.Highly, HIGHLY recommended if you enjoy your gaming to be more than the endless rinse and repeat of 'clicky clicky, blood and different colored items'.

Posted: October 18, 2015
												Very few games that I've played in my life come close to this level of storytelling. The characters and the plot are both interesting; and both of these elements get tied together with a fantastic atmosphere. Bastion presents you with a world that can easily suck you in. Combine that with gameplay that is solid and just plain fun; and I struggle to call it anything other than masterful. The game seems simple in terms of gamplay, but flexible enough to allow changes in colors and visual effects; which heavily influence the feel of the game.The content offered within the game is admirable to say the least. Bastion is smart enough to vary the gameplay a lot, so that no one thing is relied upon for the duration of the game. So, as you play, you get more things to keep you occupied. Special challenges help you with understanding different weapons. Upgrades and powerups create a very satisfying feeling of progression as the game goes on. There's just so much packed into this quaint looking game.I can hardly say a bad thing about Bastion. It's something that takes a degree of investment in, sure, but its easily worth the payoff. Just thinking about the amount of work that went into this game, to make it this immersive and intricate, makes me amazed; and I can't say that for all but the most well crafted video games.

Hacking and slashing through hordes of repetitive creatures in an isometric 3D environment would've been quite dull, weren't for the appealing art style, the always present and distinguishing voice-over narration, and the excellent soundtrack. The story, while supported by an interesting lore that can be seen reflected throughout the art of the game, doesn't get really interesting until it's final third, concluding in a very satisfatory ending. Anyway, this game is a gem. Getitgetitgetit. You won't regret it. ❤

Posted: September 30, 2013
												If I could give you a computer with Bastion installed, start the game up, and tell you to sit there and play it, I would have a much easier time explaining why this game is truly amazing.Gameplay: 9/10The gameplay is truly great, especially as far as an indie game goes. With fluid movement and skill based fights, the simple block, roll and hit gameplay is perfectly done.Level Design: 10/10Every single pixel of each level is truly a sight to behold, with the world around you forming as you walk along it, the colour and general feel of the levels sets the scene for the game flawlessly. Each part of the world has its own gimick, making each step you take an adventure in itself. I was simply entranced by this beautiful world.Music: 10/10If I could put a rating above 10/10 for this, I would in a heartbeat. Bastion uses it's music in a masterful way, where the placement and soundtrack itself if phenomenal. A simple song in the right place at the right time adds a powerful amount of emotion and feeling to parts of the baron world.Story: 10/10This is the part that makes Bastion truly magnificent. The story itself is not the real winner, but the way the story is unraveled. As the first words are spoken "Proper story's supposed to start at the beginning, ain't so simple with this one." The story is told by one man, the narrator. The main character's name is unknown, and you are playing as him as you follow the narrators story. The narrator slowly reveals everything that needs to be revealed, as if he is reading a book of a time that has already passed.Characters: 9/10The characters are never heard, but just talked about by the narrator. The characters personalities are not extremely apparent, but each one becomes special to you over time, as they are the only ones you have to share Bastion's shaken world with.Overview:Bastion is special. The soundtrack is phenomenal, the world is breathtaking, and the narration is a brilliant new idea for gaming. Finding a new enemy in a normal hack-and-slash is an uneventful affair – you kill it and move on. But in Bastion, the entire battle with Sir Lunky – a giant, colorful frog with a stone-covered head– is narrated and given soul. By the time he’s dead you know more about him than most game characters, connecting you to the world. Nearly every moment of the game is like this, continuously reinforcing your attachment to the game. You’ll be cheating yourself if you skip Bastion

Posted: November 27, 2016
												In short: Bastion rekindled my love of games. Don't get me wrong: I've always loved games. But, Bastion was so well crafted, it played like an homage that combined the best aspects of platformer-type games, story-based games, and experimental games.The platformer aspect is solid:while it's not quite a run & jump, the level itself is still a mobile obstacle that must be considered during play. The story of the game is touching and interesting, and keeps a player that cares about said story on their toes, and possibly reaching for a box of tissues. It's hard to pull off a sympathetic villain and morally ambiguous hero in any story, but I find it's even harder to do in games, where the player (as the protagonist) is putting in tons of time and energy to work against the "villain." The experiemental bit was the Narrator. Cunningham's narration may be a fixture now, but when the game was released there were a TON of people who thought that it would never work. For most, though, those fears disappeared when his rich voice started, and you always wanted to hear more of what he had to say.Supergiant Games have released just two games so far, but each of them have been gems. Bastion set them on the stage in a big way, and as their fans look forward to Pyre and beyond, it's good to recognize the game that brought the studio to us in the first place.
