Posted: January 7
												Bastion is a really compelling and very memorable top-down action/RPG with lots of heart. It has a unique tone, great music, and style to spare. It isn’t perfect by any means – the combat is slightly awkward at times and there are a few other mechanics and features that aren’t great - but the pros outweigh the cons, in my opinion. Long story short, I’d say that when it comes to art style, mood, music, and so on, the game is a strong A, while the actual mechanics are a B. Ultimately, I think that the game is stronger than its individual faults, and that the whole project as a sum package is captivating and really worth playing. If you like adventure games and retro stuff, I’d recommend Bastion in a heartbeat.+ The art style is fantastic. You know when you see great concept art for a game, and then the actual in-game graphics don’t even begin to capture that concept art? Bastion is the rare case where the in-game graphics actually achieve a large part of the wonder, scale, and mood shown in its concept art. The imagery will definitely make people stop and say, "Whoa, what are you playing?" The mission maps are filled with lots of lovingly-rendered clutter and little details, and the character designs run along this really interesting thin line between being cute and charming but also kind of rugged and tough. The visual tone does a great job of setting the mood...a little sad, a little lonely, a little dangerous. It's just an all-around striking and oftentimes stunning visual package.+ The story is actually quite solid. It seems simple at first, but it's got some unexpected depth to it. I found myself growing unexpectedly invested in the story of the Kid and his comrades. The narrator is awesome, and his voice gives the game such a unique flavor. There’s also quite a surprising amount of lore and little anecdotes that help to create the world and its backstory. By the end of the game, this feels like a truly fleshed-out and real universe with an actual history. I would love to play a full-fledged RPG set in this world, so that I could explore these environments and interact with these characters in a more thorough and in-depth way.+ As many others here have said, the music really is amazing. It’s got this electronic Western/folk vibe that is extremely evocative and works well with the visuals to produce a very cool effect…a bit lonely, a bit bittersweet, a bit exciting. The music is a huge part of why this game succeeds. The vocal songs are especially great and even beautiful. I definitely think that the original soundtrack is worth buying, some of these tracks will really stick with you for a long time.+ You've got tons of weapon variety here. I was really surprised by the number of options. You start out with a hammer and shield, but you’ll eventually get a machete, pistols, a flamethrower, a mortar cannon, a spear, trip mines, and several other weapons. You’ve also got a wide number of available super moves, some are which can be unlocked through completing special challenges with each weapon. I really loved having the ability to switch up my weapon loadout to try out different combinations; the weapons are so different that each loadout almost makes you feel like you’re playing a completely new game. If you go through most of the game using the hammer and bow, you’re going to have a very different experience from someone who swears by the calamity cannon and musket.= The combat is largely satisfying, but the ultimate effect is kind of a mixed bag.  There are some amazing, nail-biting moments of action, and there are some frustrating bits where your attacks clip through enemies or you just slog through a bunch of monsters without anything interesting happening. Some of the enemies are great, some are boring. There are some stunning highs that will make you sit up and play for another hour, and there are some lows that will make you shrug and stop playing. It can be thrilling at times and repetitive at others. The combat and mechanics ultimately average out to being simply good but not spectacular.I know that this sounds like a pretty big knock against the game - you might be saying to yourself, "Wait, so the combat is just decent and not extraordinary? Why should I bother with this game?" Despite what I'm telling you about the combat, and despite the flaws that I'll talk about in the next few points, I really believe that the overall experience of the game is very worthwhile. If you're willing to accept that this game will give you incredible atmosphere and mood alongside gameplay that is solid but occassionally flawed, I don't think that you'll be disappointed.- The platformating aspects aren’t very good…the ledges and walkways are extremely narrow and it can be way too easy to fall off the edge of a platform by mistake. This is by design and it's an obstacle that you're expected to overcome, but it’s annoying instead of dynamic or challenging. - The game is definitely rather short, and levels are all way too linear. You won’t be doing any real exploration or digging for lots of hidden treasures or alternate paths. There are a few collectible items that you can pick up, but they're not even remotely tucked away...they're all just laid out there right in front of you so that you can get them at your ease. I would have liked at least three or four additional missions, some light exploration elements, and a handful of boss battles. Really, why aren’t there any boss battles here? I think that a few bosses would have helped with the pacing and would have just given the missions a bit more focus and pay-off.- The ranged weapons have an auto-aim function that you can manually adjust, which sounds straight-forward enough, but the whole experience of aiming and adjusting was kind of clunky. Some weapons are better about this than others; the bow is pretty smooth, but others, like the mortar cannon or throwing weapons, are pretty stiff.

Posted: October 23, 2016
												Excellent game.  Graphics: Absolutely gorgeous artwork.  You could clip some of these scenes out of the game and frame them.  Everything looks hand painted and the colors are amazing.  Everything in the game looks like it belongs there and nothing is out of place.Story: Good story with excellent narration.  Not too many choices though until the end.  There were certain points where I was having trouble following it especially when I was trying to both play and listen to the narrator at the same time.  I felt like I missed some details.  I wouldn't say the story blew my mind or anything, but it was very good and certainly interesting enough to keep you engaged for the full length of the game.  The game isn't super long, which I tend to like.  I don't like dragging things on for 20+ hours.  I got through this one in about 10 and I typically take my time through it, doing different challenges and stuff like that.Gameplay: Loved the way the map floated into place as you walked down paths.  You always knew where you had been and where you could go.  It gave me incentive to explore entire rooms to see if any additional pathways were revealed. Combat was good and responsive, but the variety was more in how unique each weapon was more than how deep the combat system was. Each weapon was fun to use and they are all very different from each other.  Made it fun to mix and match to find the best fit for either your style or that particular level in the game.  But there wasn't much in the way combinations or different ways to use the same weapon.  You kind of just get into a rythm with what you are using and do that every time.  You also get to carry two weapons at once so you can kind of pair them up to match your style.  I switched weapons a lot so I can't say I ever got tired of the combat.  Soundtrack: Loved it and am considering buying it.I almost didn't complete this game because I was using a keyboard at first.  I found it very uncomfortable and fatigued my hands. Then I got a controller and went back to this and it was night and day.  While you can play it with your keyboard, I can't recommend playing this with a controller enough.If you like a good story and enjoy the top down view, hack and slash type games you owe it to yourself to check out this one.  The weapons are fun and interesting.  The music is great and the art is pleasure to play through.  Its been out a while and I'm late to the party, but I can see why the reviews are so positive.

												Please...give me...more thumbs up buttons to click, for Bastion!!!This little game swept me off my feet and reeled me in at the first few seconds of starting it...First of all - Logan Cunningham is probably the best choice -ever- to be a narrator! His calm, deep and yet somehow so soft and pleasant voice follows the player throughout the whole game, and it could not have been a better 'companion'. The little parts of story that he tells you (well, or is telling Zia, in game, whilst The Kid goes and does the hard work) are a great little adition to your adventures. A more serious look at the past of that world, a bit of a comical insert (especially if you roll off an edge. *cough* Totally not me. *cough*), a touching, warmhearting little story...all of it is like a puzzle of vocal little pieces, that you have to put together to understand what has happened in the world of Bastion. And quite honestly - it's a brilliant way of making the player 'dive into the Bastion's Universe' and enjoy the game, his own actions during the game, whilst getting told facts or stories about the world (or the particular creatures that he's fighting currently. Second - the gameplay and looks. Amazing! As in...I could not have wished for better, from a little indie (and at the current moment - already OLD indie) game! It's rather beautiful and eerie, fluently swapping between various enviroments even on the same level. Yes, of course, the actions, combat itself will be simple and noone should expect some ultra-super-duper-gazillion-slashes-in-air-in-a-wave-like-motion-before-smacking-a-mob. But I still found it extremely enjoyable. Mostly due to the fact that you actually get such a weapon and playstyle variety, that even some of the new games pale in comparison! The mix and match of the combat possibilities is amazing. Third - the soundtrack! It's brilliant! Going from a heart-pumping rythm that makes you want to score the best...to an almost tear-jerker, as you listen to some more emotional parts of the story, told by the excellent narrator....If I knew it was so amazing, I would have bought it for the full price as well! An excellent little game that kept me entertained with every second I spent on it. And oh you bet - I will be going back into it, to get those achievements and explore the rest of the weapon combinations... :D

												He decides to write a review, nah I'm just kidding.Proper story supposed to start at the beginning, its not so simple with this one.The Bastion, the last stronghold after the Calamity (a world destroying event that wrecks everything and kills almost everyone) you have to get there, restore it to its former glory and from there set on off to save the world.Bastion is a crazy awesome game, the entire game is told by the perspective of a narrator and his amazing voice. You play as "The Kid" a nameless badass who is one of the only survivors. You'll travel to exotic locations and fight a huge variety of amazing enemies. Did I mention the fact the combat in this game is amazing? A series of rolls and dodges followed by the swing of your hammer, slash of your sword, or that slow charge up for the critical hit on the bow that is the most satisfying feeling when you get it just right. Bastions combat is boosted by two major contributions:1. Bastion gives you a series of passive powerups as you progress in level. You'll find abilities in here from doing more damage to gaining health on blocking. And everytime you level up it lets you have one more of these amazing passives that can totally change the way the game works.2. Bastion gives you plenty of weapons to clear the wilds in search of cores and shards to restore the bastion. From your trusty hammer to the powerful explosive mortar, to dual pistols and a trusty carbine, to a razer sharp sword and a pike. Oh? Did I mention you get to mix and match these any way you want to? Did I also mention that every weapon has 5 upgrades slots that can range from adding damage over time, halving reload time, to adding critical chance and blast radius. You want one of video gamings best soundtracks, sure, Bastion has that too. You want a challenge? Try turning all 10 idols on (little idol statues that add difficulty to the game through means such as making enemies regenerate health or attack faster or deal double damage or even reflect your own bullets back at you, or explode on death).So we have:Amazing SoundtrackGreat CharactersSuper Awesome GameplayOne of the Best Stories EverFinal Note: Just get this. Just buy it. Its worth it.

Posted: July 11, 2014
												Bastion is, without a doubt, one of the best narrative, atmospheric, story rich indie games I have ever played. However, let’s cut right to the chase; should you pay £11 (or equiv) for this game?The straight answer is no. Why? Well, because although this game has many great aspects, for a game this short with such little depth, you pay something along the lines of £2 per hour of enjoyment. The game can be completed in less than 5 hours, and once you understand the mechanics, a second play through is completely unnecessary and adds nothing to the experience at all. Unfortunately, because this game received so much attention, its price is naturally higher to make up for the marketing budget. This is unfortunate, because if its price point was the price of an average indie game, somewhere along the lines of £6 to £8, I would have absolutely recommended it without a second thought.But, if you are wondering about whether to purchase this regardless of its price point, read on, and find out why I'd recommend this game.Firstly, Bastion's narration is some of the best I've ever heard, full stop. Not just from indie games, from AAA games too. The game is narrated in second person view; meaning as you explore and roam around the world, the narration will describe your movements and actions and directly refer to you as the character. The narrator’s voice is deep and brooding and when I first started playing it was somewhat disconcerting, largely due to the fact that the voice is slightly unnerving, and creates an atmosphere of uneasiness. However, it fits in perfectly with the themes of the game. I also love the way in which the story is presented through pretty much only the use of the narrative. At one point, you spot a man who is still alive amongst a mass of dead people, frozen into stone. The narrator however knows more than the boy you play as, and says “Just think, if we didn’t have people like him, we wouldn’t be in this mess, would we.” The character you play knows nothing about who this man is or why he’s any different from anyone else, but the narrator does. If I hadn’t replayed this part of the game, I wouldn’t have remembered that such an event occurs. It adds a refreshing layer into a game which otherwise may have held very little replayabiliy.Another point is that this game does a magnificent job of engrossing you into the world. The soundtrack is fantastic, and, without a doubt, the greatest redeeming aspect of Bastion is its absolutely beautiful art style. It oozes with passion and you get the general sense that someone loved every second they drew the stunning watercolour masterpieces you see throughout the whole game. You control a character only known as 'The Kid', of which very little is known, or is ever known, apart from that he served in the military. Along the way, you gather increasing attachment to this silent hero who receives no thanks despite never stopping and never giving up. The world is reliant on him, and he pushes forward, absolutely emotionlessly, and this dark, brooding nature raises real questions about such a mysterious character. Honestly, I think the fact that we only learn tiny snippets about the character is one of the best things the developers did to this game. More often than not, character progression can go too far or not far enough, but in this case, it’s pretty much perfect for the type of game it is. I felt the slightest twinge of empathy when I learnt of The Kid’s situation, but not enough for me to feel like I was forced into feelings of depression or sadness, and was rather presented with facts and allowed to feel as I naturally would. There are a few downsides, none of which I’d really say demean Bastion’s brilliance to an extent that I’d consider it not worth playing, but I will mention them briefly regardless. A massive lack of replayability plagues this game. There is really no reason to want to replay this game. There aren’t any difficult choices which lead you upon a different path, there aren’t any new weapons or characters to find. It’s largely based on an immersive first playthrough. This leads to the question of value for money, as to which it isn’t great.I found slight trouble with keyboard controls, and I’d greatly recommend a controller, as it makes exploring much smoother and enjoyable. Once I started to use a controller, I felt like I understood some of the mechanics much better.It also suffers from a general lack of any sort of character progress in terms of stats. It’s not an RPG; in reality it’s more of a story-telling experience in which you play the protagonist. You have weapon upgrades, but even they fall somewhat through, since they’re largely passive and can be overlooked almost entirely.When it comes down to it, I would recommend this game. Why? Perhaps not for its merit as a video game, since the mechanics are somewhat forgettable and simple, but instead because of its merit as a work of art. After you play this game, if ever someone proclaims the infamous ‘video games cannot be art’ statement, you will be infuriated, thrust Bastion in their face and declare them a ♥♥♥♥ing idiotic moron.

												Bastion is properly one of the most original game experiences I have ever tryed in mt life.This game is a overwiev shotter, and it is very well crafted. The idea gameplay wise is, that you travel from land to land, and try to recover something from each land. Along the way you will find diffrent weapons, upgrades and powerups to help you on your quest.The weapons is one of my favorite aspects of the game, simply becouse non of the weapons felt alike, at least to me. You could chosse a fast gun with low damage, a charging gun with high damage, a quick sord you could throw, a hammer with a lot of damage and so on. Why I loved this aspect so much, is becouse it changed the way you played, and you could try diffrent things and upgrades out, in order to find the combination of weapons, that suited you the best. Let`s talk about the main world, so the idea is that you are trying to rebuild a thing called the Bastion, and when you rebuild a part of it, new things will be unlocked. I will talk more about the Bastion later when it comed to the story. The places you unlock is for eksample the weapon store I already talked about. Then there is a posion store, where you can give youself boosts. Then there is a challenge board, that will show you diffrent things you can do, in order to achive more curency. Thn there is the ideal store, where you can activate god ideals, in order to get a harder challengee, but get mroe XP and money. The overall gameplay is fluid and actionpackt, and when you fail or get hit, I never blamied the controles, I blamied myself. I knew I made a mistake, and I made sure,I did not do the same thing again. I simply loved the overall gamepaly aspekt becouse of this.Now I want to combine the story, the worlds, the challenges, the bosses and the music into one part simply becouse they work so fluid together. The story is told through a naorator, who is called the old man. You play as the kid, and every thing happening, is told through the old man. This means the game is like one big storytelling, and it really sets the tone, and makes humores things happening, becouse of the way the old man is. Every single world and challenge fells uniqe becouse of the old man , he tells lore to the palces and the overall landscape and worldbehavior is diffrent nearly every single time. The music to every single stage is beutifully crafted, and I highly recormend getting the soundtrack somewhere becouse it is beutyful. So the world you live in, has been blown up, by a bomb, and the old man, tells you, he maybe can fix it with the Bastion. Therfore you must rebuild parts of the Bastion one by one, and afterwards power the Bastion up. Along the way you incounder more survivers of the bomb, and that esculates into more story development. One of the survivers wants to attack you, becouse he finds out something about the bomb, but I will not spoil it. The bosses in this game are all amazing, and they all prove to be a great challenge to you. The ending of the game is amazing, and it really made me fell full of emeotion for the charecters in the game. The last choice you have to make was so hard for me, that I at least stood there for 5 minuts and thought it through, becouse of the big change it would to to the charecters I had experienced this great adventure with.Overall this game is amazing, it delevered such an impact on me, becouse of the overall presentation, and the amzing experience it delevred to me. I highly recormend this game, thumps up. 9 out of 10

 Near perfect. Almost has everything a game needs. Let's start with what is possibly one of the best example of voice acting in video game to this date. The narrator, who gives a commentary on your adventure in past tense even though you are playing through this story in the future, is amazing. His voice is godly, emotionless at time but look (or listen) closer and you'll start to learn much more about him. He does a perfect job. Not to mention the wonderful combat system where with all the combinations of weapons and challenge modes will keep you interested and sweating if you want but if you don't, it's really fluent and frustration-free to just experience the story. Beautiful design with both the storytelling and arts fascinating. With no strings attached you get to have your choice and be deeply moved/reflect a lot. At least I personally had gained unimagined insights and edifications from it unaccessible elsewhere, seriously. (Don't want to be too specific lest it becomes a spoiler)I really enjoyed Bastion because it had a gripping story to tell me. I felt like I was playing a book. Emotionally invested is the right word choice. In all, games that touch our hearts are so rare these days, yet Bastion does it wonderfully, and genuinely, unlike some games which claim to do so but really don't; what's more is it also achieves amazing playability along with the story. Buy it, you won't regret it because it's that good.

Posted: July 17, 2014
												I really can't recommend enough that you play this game. I just finished it and it is one of the best I've ever played. It is an action RPG, though with emphasis on the action with and incredibly engaging story and amazing music.The real strength of this game is story and story telling. There is a Narrator who is telling this story and he has a lot to say. Most reviews I've seen say he narrates "everything you do". This is not correct, and thankfully so, because that would get dull. No, the strength of the Narrator is that he MIGHT comment on ANYTHING you do. You never know when you'll get a comment. It might be because you just beat up a big group of enemies without getting hit, or because you fell off the ledge a lot. He is also constantly giving you insight into the city before "The Calamity", a catastrophic even that happened right before the game starts. I found myself not really caring what the Calamity was, but wanting to know everything about the city before. He tells you how many of the monsters you fight aren't monsters, but creatures that actually had important roles in society before the Calamity changed them and the world. There is even one scene that tries to make you feel bad for them, though once I recognized that, I felt it somewhat contrived.The plot is also good, with information being given to you slowly, so you keep pushing forward so the Narrator will tell you more about what happened or what is going on. There are actually two choices at the end, which surprised me. The last choice had me thinking like no game ever has. I couldn't decide for awhile! I'm going to play New Game + to see the other side of both. There is also a scene where you base is attacked, and the game made me angry with just a few small words "Our little [pet]... didn't make it". It's something special to draw out emotion like that.The action is fun. The combat comes in spurts, with some running around and listening (more on that later) so you have a breather and don't really feel overwhelmed. On the one hand, this makes the game easy, but it also keeps it from being boring.  Don't look for really stong RPG elements, as leveling is slow and only allows you to carry one more "tonic" which give benefits. You gain the tonics themselves independently. Some are found and some are bought. But there are a lot of weapons and each has 5 upgrage tiers, with 2 options for each tier and you can switch them whenever you want. There is a 2 weapon system, so you will probably find a favorite combo.Finally, the music is also awesome. In most games, you might be too busy with the action to focus much on music, but the way this game plays, especially with the pauses between fights, you can really pay attention to the music. It is a fantastic soundtrack and fits the setting, which I'd describe a mix between fantasy and western, as odd as that might sound. A few tracks include excellent vocals.This is a fantastic game, well worth your $15, and I'm the guy that waits for everything to go on sale. Buy it, buy it now!

												Bastion is, without a doubt in my mind, one of the best video games to come out of a low budget development teams ever. It is a game that can be considered a masterpiece, but let me delve into the why. For one on a presentation level the game looks amazing, handdrawn and extremely artistic backdrops help liven up the hack and slash fun within Bastion. The voice acting is done by amazing actor Logan Cunningham. Logan narrates almost every move and decision you make throughout the game. For example near the begining of the game if you fall off any of the map edges you will be presented with a well delevered witty comment saying "And then the kid fell to his death [Short Pause]. I'm just kidding" This goes through the whole game and all story is explaned through the narrators comments about the fall of the world (Also known as 'The Calamity') and also the backstory of the kid and all his fellows within the Bastion. And while there are many elements as to the background of the world and the characters within it there are many hints to events which make cause for tons of speculation. On top of all this Bastion has increadibly fun hack and slash gameplay. Bastion has you using various diffrent weapons at your disposle to get the job done. The game isnt too challangeing but lucky the game even has a feature where you can anger the gods making the game much harder. Finally it wouldn't be a Bastion review without stating how genius the soundtrack is. Every track evokes tons of emotions that either fill the heart with saddness or fill your spirit with power fantasy. If this review wasnt enough to convince you go watch a trailer and just see how increadible the art, voice acting, story and sound track are in this masterpiece of a game.-AUS ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

Posted: July 6, 2014
												Bastion is one of my favourite games ever. First of all, everything about it is stunning. The voice acting, music, artwork, and design are all top notch; I immediately downloaded the soundtrack in the middle of my first playthrough. It's a pretty short game - it usually takes me about 8-10 hours to finish if I mess around in it, but I replay it over and over. There are different modes to unlock after you finish the first story mode that allow for different ways to enjoy it, although as far as I can tell only one new thing appears, besides some amusing (if subtle) commentary changes. -The play style is basically point-shoot and it's sort of like a 3D platformer, but I haven't played any games like it before, so it gets a +1 for being original. -The story isn't the most original but it is compelling and fun to listen to (it's narrated by one of the characters), and I always get a bit choked up at the end. -There are a ton of weapon possibilities, since there are maybe 15 different weapons to choose from and you can have two at a time, plus a 'special' skill of which there are a lot more (25 maybe? Not sure).-It's also not particularly difficult, but there are up to 10 'idols' available that can make it basically impossible (yay, 'chivos!).-The story is mainly linear, with some 'detour' areas until the very last little bit, where you have to make two decisions. Neither of them are "good vs evil!", which I like a lot because both times the decisions are hard to make and during my first playthrough I knew I'd be playing it over again so that I could choose the other. Each time it's heartwrenching, despite the fact that I've tried all four combinations. Even though the story stays the same (besides the outcome), I enjoy the replays, as I've already mentioned. Overall, probably 8/10 from me, but only because it's so short and there aren't enough tracks.

												He decides to write a review, nah I'm just kidding.Proper story supposed to start at the beginning, its not so simple with this one.The Bastion, the last stronghold after the Calamity (a world destroying event that wrecks everything and kills almost everyone) you have to get there, restore it to its former glory and from there set on off to save the world.Bastion is a crazy awesome game, the entire game is told by the perspective of a narrator and his amazing voice. You play as "The Kid" a nameless badass who is one of the only survivors. You'll travel to exotic locations and fight a huge variety of amazing enemies. Did I mention the fact the combat in this game is amazing? A series of rolls and dodges followed by the swing of your hammer, slash of your sword, or that slow charge up for the critical hit on the bow that is the most satisfying feeling when you get it just right. Bastions combat is boosted by two major contributions:1. Bastion gives you a series of passive powerups as you progress in level. You'll find abilities in here from doing more damage to gaining health on blocking. And everytime you level up it lets you have one more of these amazing passives that can totally change the way the game works.2. Bastion gives you plenty of weapons to clear the wilds in search of cores and shards to restore the bastion. From your trusty hammer to the powerful explosive mortar, to dual pistols and a trusty carbine, to a razer sharp sword and a pike. Oh? Did I mention you get to mix and match these any way you want to? Did I also mention that every weapon has 5 upgrades slots that can range from adding damage over time, halving reload time, to adding critical chance and blast radius. You want one of video gamings best soundtracks, sure, Bastion has that too. You want a challenge? Try turning all 10 idols on (little idol statues that add difficulty to the game through means such as making enemies regenerate health or attack faster or deal double damage or even reflect your own bullets back at you, or explode on death).So we have:Amazing SoundtrackGreat CharactersSuper Awesome GameplayOne of the Best Stories EverFinal Note: Just get this. Just buy it. Its worth it.

Posted: July 21, 2014
												I had a lot of fun playing through this game so I figured I would do a quick review:Story:The story for Bastion was incredibly unique. For a game that is the price of a meal at a fast food reasturant (at least at the time I purchased it), Bastion delivers a well thought out tale that strings the levels together, without burdening you to pay attention to every detail in the game in order to understand it. The intrigue of the storyline is largely due to the brilliance of the added narrarator. The narrator truly kept the game intersting and enjoyable. Somehow, even dying early on in the game wasnt a drag due to the narrarator spewing out one of his quick blurbs right after you die such as "Just kidding, that's not what happened". The story isn't going to wow you like the Bioshock series, but it still has a fair share of twists and turns to keep you on the edge of your seat.Graphics:There seems to be a trend in indie games having unique graphics as part of the appeal. Either as retro 8 bit or more stylized. Bastion is no exeption. It has a very distinctive look with its fluorescent colours and lush hand painted environments. Bastion breaks away from the tedium of other platform games of its type. The reason I say that it breaks away is because of Bastion's unique style of varying environments. Unlike even some AAA games, Bastion is constantly changing the levels colour spectrum, enemies, and overall feel. From floating urban settings, to swamps and jungles, and finally to snow filled caverns. All the while, your presented to well made landscapes that are visually impressive due to their distinctiveness. As a side note, this game is not graphically intensive and runs on my basic Dell labtop perfectly.Gameplay:Bastion boasts a customizable expereince that categorizes it as an RPG. There is a wealth of close and far weapons that are really dependent on the player. Personally, I never really had a bread and butter loadout, but even if you look online, every setup is viable. Very few people have the same setup, as by the end of the game you are given so many options that your loadout is tailored to your personal play style and strategy. The charecter you play as, simply known as "The Kid", is very responsive and quick on his feet. The controls and movement are solid and tight. never will you worry about the gamer's dreaded "Button Lag". Bastion offers a solid layer of strategy due to your loadout  which includes your two weapons, a secret skill, and your selection of spirits. The weapons are all customizable allowing you to vary up even further how you want to play. A simple machete can be used as a fast, posion inducing blade, maybe a critical hit machine for taking down bigger foes, or even used as a sort of javelin. The options really alter the gameplay. Along with your weapons is your secret skill. The skills are extremely varied. Some are based on which weapon you have equiped, while others such as a hand grenade, or a skill that makes enemies fight for you, are independent from your weapons. Finally, is your spirits which you gain more slots for by leveling up. In other words, higher level=more passive bonuses. These drinks truely alter gameplay. Some boost basic things like health or your critical hit chance, while others can help you survive a blow that would have killed you.Sound:Unforunately, I am not a huge sound guy. I don't play games with headphones and therefore might miss the immersion that a shooter might bring with it's explosvie array of sounds. As for Bastion though, I was actually quite suprised with its sounds. Combat sounds were rich the feeling of a gun actually packing a punch. Blades had a slicing sound that made them seem as though they actually cut something instead of just air wooshing by. And the best part of Bastion's sounds, is its soundtrack. Very few times do i play games and find myself humming a tune from it hours later. Not the case with Bastion. The soundtrack is spectacular and suprised me with how catchy and infectious it was.Replayability/ length:In the case of Bastion, there is reason to go back and replay the story. After completing the game for the first time,  I was only around level 5 or so. There are 10 levels total that I know of, and with levels comes more spirits and more gameplay options. Plus, there is so much customization that can be had, that one playthrough means you neglected at least a weapon or two. Unfortunately for Bastion though, the replayability and it's length are the one true flaw for me. No spoilers, but towards the end of the game you make a few choices that seem like they would have a big impact. To great dismay, you never see the impact, there is hardly an epilogue showcasing what occured due to your final choice and so, that segment of the game seems almost unneccasary. This means that going back through the game to make a different choice is almost pointless. While I am already bashing Bastion, I have to bring up how it is very short. You can easily complete the game in a solid day or two. Combine that with a lack of story differential between playthroughs and this game could be a play, beat, and  collect dust depending on the person. In my humble opinion, I have yet to get bored, but I must mention, for the person wishing to spend hundreds of hours on a game, this probably isn't for you.In conclusion, Bastion offers a great amount of enjoyment for a small fee. Although a tad short, it will keep you entertained the ride through with its amazing soundtrack, broad amount of  customization options, and a distinct art style that warrant this little gem an 9/10 from me.

 Near perfect. Almost has everything a game needs. Let's start with what is possibly one of the best example of voice acting in video game to this date. The narrator, who gives a commentary on your adventure in past tense even though you are playing through this story in the future, is amazing. His voice is godly, emotionless at time but look (or listen) closer and you'll start to learn much more about him. He does a perfect job. Not to mention the wonderful combat system where with all the combinations of weapons and challenge modes will keep you interested and sweating if you want but if you don't, it's really fluent and frustration-free to just experience the story. Beautiful design with both the storytelling and arts fascinating. With no strings attached you get to have your choice and be deeply moved/reflect a lot. At least I personally had gained unimagined insights and edifications from it unaccessible elsewhere, seriously. (Don't want to be too specific lest it becomes a spoiler)I really enjoyed Bastion because it had a gripping story to tell me. I felt like I was playing a book. Emotionally invested is the right word choice. In all, games that touch our hearts are so rare these days, yet Bastion does it wonderfully, and genuinely, unlike some games which claim to do so but really don't; what's more is it also achieves amazing playability along with the story. Buy it, you won't regret it because it's that good.

												Bastion is properly one of the most original game experiences I have ever tryed in mt life.This game is a overwiev shotter, and it is very well crafted. The idea gameplay wise is, that you travel from land to land, and try to recover something from each land. Along the way you will find diffrent weapons, upgrades and powerups to help you on your quest.The weapons is one of my favorite aspects of the game, simply becouse non of the weapons felt alike, at least to me. You could chosse a fast gun with low damage, a charging gun with high damage, a quick sord you could throw, a hammer with a lot of damage and so on. Why I loved this aspect so much, is becouse it changed the way you played, and you could try diffrent things and upgrades out, in order to find the combination of weapons, that suited you the best. Let`s talk about the main world, so the idea is that you are trying to rebuild a thing called the Bastion, and when you rebuild a part of it, new things will be unlocked. I will talk more about the Bastion later when it comed to the story. The places you unlock is for eksample the weapon store I already talked about. Then there is a posion store, where you can give youself boosts. Then there is a challenge board, that will show you diffrent things you can do, in order to achive more curency. Thn there is the ideal store, where you can activate god ideals, in order to get a harder challengee, but get mroe XP and money. The overall gameplay is fluid and actionpackt, and when you fail or get hit, I never blamied the controles, I blamied myself. I knew I made a mistake, and I made sure,I did not do the same thing again. I simply loved the overall gamepaly aspekt becouse of this.Now I want to combine the story, the worlds, the challenges, the bosses and the music into one part simply becouse they work so fluid together. The story is told through a naorator, who is called the old man. You play as the kid, and every thing happening, is told through the old man. This means the game is like one big storytelling, and it really sets the tone, and makes humores things happening, becouse of the way the old man is. Every single world and challenge fells uniqe becouse of the old man , he tells lore to the palces and the overall landscape and worldbehavior is diffrent nearly every single time. The music to every single stage is beutifully crafted, and I highly recormend getting the soundtrack somewhere becouse it is beutyful. So the world you live in, has been blown up, by a bomb, and the old man, tells you, he maybe can fix it with the Bastion. Therfore you must rebuild parts of the Bastion one by one, and afterwards power the Bastion up. Along the way you incounder more survivers of the bomb, and that esculates into more story development. One of the survivers wants to attack you, becouse he finds out something about the bomb, but I will not spoil it. The bosses in this game are all amazing, and they all prove to be a great challenge to you. The ending of the game is amazing, and it really made me fell full of emeotion for the charecters in the game. The last choice you have to make was so hard for me, that I at least stood there for 5 minuts and thought it through, becouse of the big change it would to to the charecters I had experienced this great adventure with.Overall this game is amazing, it delevered such an impact on me, becouse of the overall presentation, and the amzing experience it delevred to me. I highly recormend this game, thumps up. 9 out of 10

The narrator narrates based on your actions, whether you're rushing through a map, or standing still often. The gameplay isn't the best, but it works fine for what it is, and is still quite enjoyable. This game really got me right in the feels, it is very well done. The only downside is the length of the game. I finished it in only a few hours. That being said, i feel the story and general quality of the game makes up for the length, and i highly recommend it.
